content:
༄༅༅། །
In the language of India [Sanskrit]: Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra [The Way of the Bodhisattva] In Tibetan: A Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life Homage to all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. With reverence I prostrate with body, speech and mind to all the perfectly-gone, never-returning Sugatas possessing the twofold dharmakāya,
Together with their noble heirs born from wisdom and compassion, and all who are worthy of veneration.
The entrance into the threefold discipline of these children of the Sugatas—restraint, virtue-gathering, and benefiting beings—
I shall now concisely explain according to authentic scripture, suitable for beings of these degenerate times. I have nothing new to say here that has not been said before.
Nor do I possess any skill in composition.
Therefore, I have not written this with the intention to benefit others.
I have composed this solely to cultivate my own mind. For cultivating virtue, my force of faith
Shall, for the time being, increase through these verses.
And should others of equal spiritual fortune
Chance upon these teachings, they too will find their path fulfilled. This precious human life with its eight freedoms and ten endowments,
So rare to find—like a blind turtle meeting a floating yoke—enables the highest Dharma purpose.
If, having obtained this fleeting treasure through past virtue, you fail to practice the holy Dharma,
How could such perfect conditions ever be gathered again as death approaches uncertainty? Just as in the night's darkness midst dense clouds
Lightning momentarily illuminates with brilliant light
So too by Buddha's power, once in a hundred times
Wisdom and merit briefly arise in worldly beings' minds Therefore virtue remains perpetually feeble,
While sin's power is mighty and utterly unbearable.
What virtue other than the mind of perfect enlightenment
Could possibly overcome such terrible forces? Having thoroughly contemplated over countless eons,
The Lords of Sages perceived that this alone brings benefit;
Through this, countless multitudes of beings
Effortlessly attain supreme bliss. Those who wish to overcome hundreds of sufferings of existence,
Who desire to dispel the unhappiness of sentient beings,
Who wish to experience hundreds of happinesses, both temporary and ultimate—
Should never, ever abandon bodhicitta, the awakening mind. The moment bodhicitta awakens in one's mind,
The wretched one, once bound in saṃsāra's prison,
Is instantly proclaimed a child of the Sugatas,
And becomes worthy of prostrations from gods and humans throughout the world. Like the supreme alchemical elixir that transforms into gold,
Taking this impure body and transmuting it into the priceless, jewel-like form of the Victorious One,
Therefore, firmly grasp without wavering
This supreme mind of awakening called bodhicitta. The world's sole captains, with wisdom immeasurable and all-pervading,
Having thoroughly examined all phenomena through countless eons, found most precious,
Those who wish to be freed from samsara's realms of wandering,
Firmly grasp this supreme jewel—the jewel of bodhicitta. All other virtuous deeds, like a plantain tree,
Will ultimately be exhausted after bearing fruit.
Yet the wish-fulfilling tree of bodhicitta
Bears fruit without depletion, ever growing in abundance. Even if one has committed most terrible negative acts,
Just as one escapes grave dangers by relying on a hero,
Which instantly liberates one when relied upon,
Why would those conscientious about proper conduct not depend on it? Like the fire at the end of time that consumes all worlds, bodhicitta
Instantly burns away even the five heinous crimes.
These immeasurable benefits
The wise protector Maitreya explained to Sudhana, noble merchant's son. That bodhicitta, in brief,
Should be understood as having two aspects:
The aspirational mind toward enlightenment,
And the engagement in enlightenment itself. Just as one discerns the difference between
Wishing to go and actually going somewhere,
So should the wise understand
These two types in sequence. Though the aspiring mind of awakening bodhipraṇidhicitta yields
Great fruits while wandering in saṃsāra,
It does not generate continuous merit
As does the engaging mind prasthānacitta. From the moment one firmly takes up that engagement bodhichitta
For the sake of liberating the boundless realm of sentient beings,
With an irreversible mind that will not turn back—
A merit vast as space flows ceaselessly, even in sleep and inattention, From the moment one formally takes the engaged bodhicitta vow
Powerful streams of merit, vast as space itself
Flow forth unceasingly in boundless measure
Even during sleep or times of heedlessness This teaching on engaged bodhicitta,
Was expounded by the Tathāgata himself,
For the sake of beings of inferior motivation,
Those śrāvakas who turned away from the Mahāyāna path. When one merely thinks of the headaches of beings,
'I shall dispel them'—even just this thought,
This compassionate intent to benefit others,
Endows one with immeasurable merit. Wishing to remove
The immeasurable sufferings of each and every being,
And aspiring to establish each one in boundless qualities
Of enlightenment—what need is there to speak of such merit? What mother or father could possess such altruistic intention?
Who has such wish for others to attain Buddhahood?
Not even among gods and truth-speaking sages,
Nor even in Brahma himself, does this profound concern exist. For these very beings
Even for their own sake, this wish
Not even in dreams has such a thought ever appeared
How then could it possibly arise for the benefit of others? Others do not generate even for their own sake
The mind that contemplates the welfare of sentient beings
This special jewel of mind bodhicitta
Has arisen—an unprecedented marvel The cause of joy for all wandering beings,
The elixir for the suffering of all sentient beings,
This precious mind whose merit is boundless,
How could one possibly measure such merit? Even through the mere intention to benefit others,
One surpasses the merit of making offerings to Buddhas.
What need is there to mention striving
For the happiness of all sentient beings without exception? Though beings wish to be free from suffering,
They rush toward suffering itself like moths to flames.
Though longing for happiness through present and future lives,
Through delusion about what to adopt and reject,
They destroy their own happiness as if it were an enemy. To those who are deprived of joy,
And burdened with manifold sufferings,
May I bring fulfillment through happiness,
And sever completely all suffering. It even dispels ignorance.
Where is virtue equal to this?
Where is such a beneficial friend?
Where is merit like this? One who repays kindness received is, for now, deemed praiseworthy,
What need, then, to mention the bodhisattva who,
Without being asked, performs virtuous deeds,
What need, then, to mention the bodhisattva? One who provides ordinary meals to merely a few people,
Is honored as virtuous by the world, though their gift is slight,
Whether giving food for just a moment's sustenance,
Or providing half a day's nourishment with disdain. That bestows upon limitless beings throughout endless time
The unsurpassed bliss of the Tathāgatas,
Completely fulfilling all wishes in every mind until space and beings are no more?
What need is there to mention the inexhaustible generosity Whoever harbors malice in their heart
Toward a Bodhisattva, the Victor's heir who serves as patron,
Will dwell in the hell realms for as many kalpas
As moments of ill will generated—thus the Sage declared. However, if one generates a mind of pure devotion,
The fruits thereof will multiply far more abundantly.
For the children of the Conqueror, even under great duress,
No negativity arises, while virtuous qualities naturally increase. I prostrate to the bodies of those
In whom that precious jewel of supreme bodhicitta has arisen
I go for refuge to those sources of happiness
Who transform even harmful acts into connections with happiness. Thus concludes the first chapter from the 'Introduction to the Conduct of Bodhisattvas' Bodhicaryāvatāra, entitled 'Explanation of the Benefits of Bodhicitta.' To generate and hold this precious bodhicitta mind,
I make perfect offerings to the Tathāgatas and the sublime Dharma,
To the immaculate jewel free from all conceptual elaborations,
And to the Buddha's children, the Bodhisattvas—these oceans of qualities. Whatever flowers and fruits there are in existence,
And whatever varieties of medicines there are in existence,
And whatever precious substances exist in the world,
And whatever pure, delightful waters there are in existence. mountains of precious jewels like Meru and golden peaks
forest realms secluded peaceful as turquoise mandalas
trees resplendent adorned with blossoming flower ornaments
and those whose branches bow low bearing excellent fruits In the realms of gods and celestial beings, there are divine fragrances and incense,
Wish-fulfilling trees and trees made of precious gems,
Crops that grow without being cultivated,
And other ornaments worthy of offering. Oceans and lakes adorned with lotuses,
Swans with beautiful and pleasing songs,
Throughout the vast expanse of space to its limits,
All these that cannot be possessed. Having gathered with my mind the supreme sage, the best of humans,
I present these well to him and his heirs.
May these holy recipients with immense compassion,
Accept my offerings with kindness, considering me with love. I am without merit and greatly impoverished;
I possess nothing else whatsoever for offerings;
Therefore, O compassionate protectors, who think only of others' welfare;
Please accept these through your miraculous powers, for my benefit. I offer myself completely to the Victorious Ones and to all their spiritual heirs;
Throughout all lifetimes, I permanently surrender my entire being, relinquishing all self-clinging.
O Supreme Bodhisattvas, please accept me fully as your own;
With reverence, I become your servant to benefit all beings and transcend my negative actions. Having surrendered myself completely into your care,
I remain fearless in saṃsāra while working for beings' welfare.
I shall transcend my previous negative deeds,
And henceforth commit no further wrongdoing. In those exceedingly fragrant bathing chambers
With floors of crystal that are clear and brilliantly gleaming
Adorned with captivating pillars of radiant jewels
Covered with canopies that shimmer with the luminous glow of pearls To the Tathāgatas and their spiritual children,
I offer ablution with numerous gemstone vessels
Filled with fragrant, mind-pleasing waters,
Accompanied by melodious songs and musical instruments. With incomparable garments of divine cloth and Kāśika silk,
I cleanse their sacred bodies with perfumed, immaculate cloths,
Then I offer them excellent robes well-dyed in the three allowable colors,
Presenting supremely fragrant, exquisite vestments. With divine garments—soft, smooth, and splendidly varied in form,
And the finest ornaments of countless kinds adorning them,
I honor noble Samantabhadra, wise Manjushri,
And Lokeshvara, Lord of the World, along with other exalted bodhisattvas. With supreme fragrances whose sweet scents pervade the entire trichiliocosm,
I anoint the bodies of all the Lords of Sages with these finest scents.
Like pure gold well-melted, thoroughly refined, and perfectly polished,
Their radiant forms brilliantly blaze with captivating light. I worship the supreme Lords of Sages, most worthy of reverence,
With mandārava, lotus, and all fragrant flowers delightful to the mind;
With utpala and all other fragrant items,
And beautifully arranged garlands that are pleasing to the mind. I offer billowing clouds of fragrant incense with rich aromas spreading, delightfully captivating the mind.
I present various delectable foods, edible delights, and drinks—divine offerings worthy of the exalted ones.
With rich aromas spreading, delightfully captivating the mind.
Divine offerings worthy of the exalted ones I reverently serve. I mentally offer jeweled lamps upon rows of gleaming golden lotuses of Jambu,
Placed on golden lotus arrangements, their radiant light dispelling the darkness of ignorance.
On gem-inlaid floors anointed with fragrant substances the thickness of a cow's hide,
I scatter pleasing stemless flower petals, spread knee-high across this sacred ground. I offer these celestial mansions adorned with pearl and jewel necklaces
Resplendent ornaments of the quarters where enchanting hymns of praise resound
These clouds of divine palaces illuminating the boundless sky with their beauty
To those whose nature is compassion that all beings may reach liberation's realm I offer these magnificent jeweled parasols with golden handles,
Adorned with precious gems and auspicious patterns in splendid array,
Beautifully shaped and raised aloft, delightful to behold,
These I continuously present to the mighty sages. Furthermore, may magnificent clouds of offerings stand forth,
With instruments played, struck, and blown with their eight sublime qualities,
May clouds of music and melody that delight the mind and soothe,
Relieving all beings' suffering, pervade before the Victorious Ones and their heirs. Upon all precious Dharma jewels, both scriptural and realized,
Upon stupas of Buddha's eight activities and images painted, cast, and sculpted,
May showers of jewels, flowers, and manifold offerings
Fall incessantly without interruption until samsara ends. Just as Mañjuśrī, Samantabhadra and others
Make magnificent offerings to the Victorious Ones,
So shall I make offerings to the Tathāgata protectors
Together with their spiritual heirs. I praise the oceans of qualities—the Buddha Blessed Ones with their physical marks, Brahma-voice, and omniscient wisdom—and their bodhisattva heirs
With oceans of melodious expressions of praise, where melody is speech, limbs are its causes, and ocean signifies their multiplicity.
May these sweet clouds of eulogizing melodies
Definitely arise before them perpetually in all times and places, even without my continuous offering. To all Buddhas throughout the three times,
Together with the sublime Dharma and supreme Assembly,
With bodies as numerous as atoms in all buddha-fields,
I reverently bow down and prostrate myself. I bow to all stūpas and the foundations of the awakening mind.
I pay homage to the preceptors,
I likewise venerate the teachers,
Those of supreme disciplined conduct. Until I reach the essence of enlightenment,
I go for refuge to the Buddhas.
To the Dharma and the assembly of Bodhisattvas,
Likewise, I go for refuge. To those dwelling in all directions,
The perfectly awakened Buddhas and the bodhisattvas,
All who possess great compassion,
With joined palms, I make this supplication. From beginningless saṃsāra,
In this life or in other births,
I have committed naturally wrongful deeds,
Or directed others to do the same. Overwhelmed by ignorance and confusion,
Whatever actions I've rejoiced in,
Having recognized these wrongdoings,
I confess to the Protector with all my heart. Whatever harm I have inflicted on the Three Jewels,
And on my parents or spiritual teachers or others,
Through the afflictions, by means of my body, speech,
And mind—all this I hereby confess. I, defiled by numerous faults like attachment clinging like rust,
A sinner who has committed utterly unbearable harmful deeds,
All these terrible sins that I have done, which may bring death at any moment,
With genuine remorse I confess before all guides—the Buddhas and their heirs. With my negative actions still unpurified,
I will be taken by the Lord of Death prematurely.
How can I be definitively liberated from these misdeeds?
I implore you, protect me swiftly, that I may take refuge! The Lord of Death, utterly beyond trust,
Waits not for deeds done or yet unbegun.
Whether healthy or sick, life is but a breath—
Never trust this fleeting life will endure. Not knowing I must abandon everything and depart utterly alone,
I committed numerous sins through attachment and aversion,
For the sake of those dear to me and against those not dear,
All meaningless actions that bring only suffering when I depart. Enemies shall cease to exist;
Dear ones too shall be no more;
I myself shall likewise perish;
Thus everything shall come to nothing. Just as with experiences in a dream,
Whatever objects one experiences
Become merely objects of memory,
All that has passed will not be seen again. Even in this very life, while you yet remain,
Many beloved and non-beloved ones have passed away;
Yet the unbearable evil deeds committed through attachment and aversion
Stand before you. Thus I have not realized
I am but a sudden, temporary visitor in this world.
Through delusion, attachment, and hatred
I have committed many types of sins. Day and night without respite,
Life constantly diminishes with no way to replenish,
No additional time comes from elsewhere,
How can I not meet death, I will surely die. Though I lie here on my deathbed
Surrounded by all my relatives and friends
The unbearable pain of life being severed
I alone must endure. When seized by the messengers of the Lord of Death,
What help can relatives provide? What benefit are friends?
At that critical moment, only merit serves as a refuge,
Yet even that I have not cultivated. O Protector, through my heedlessness,
Not knowing these terrifying fears,
For the sake of this impermanent life,
I have committed many evil deeds. Led today to where his limbs will be severed as punishment
The condemned man withers, gripped by terror profound
Parched with thirst, his gaze downcast and pitiful
He himself appears utterly transformed from before. What more can be said of one seized by Yama's messengers
With terrifying forms—manifestations of one's own karma—
Afflicted by the great disease of terror,
Overwhelmed with dread while facing death's final torments? Who will properly protect me from
This great terror? thinking thus,
With terrified eyes agape,
I frantically search in all four directions for refuge. Seeing no refuge in the four directions,
I fall utterly into overwhelming despair.
In that terrifying place where no protection exists,
What shall I do then? Thus to the Victor, the protector of beings,
Who strive for the purpose of defending all beings,
The powerful one who dispels all fears,
From this very day I go for refuge. I take genuine refuge in the Dharma realized by the Buddhas
Which dispels all saṃsāra's fears;
And likewise in the noble assembly of bodhisattvas,
I sincerely take refuge without doubt. Overwhelmed with terror from fears,
I offer myself to Samantabhadra.
To Mañjuśrī as well,
I surrender this body. With compassionate activity that is unerring,
To that Lord Avalokiteśvara,
I cry out with a pitiful wail,
May he protect me, a sinner. To noble Ākāśagarbha, Buddha-appointed staff-like support for fallen bodhisattvas,
To Kṣitigarbha, protector of the destitute overcome by afflictions though wearing monastic robes,
And to all great compassionate protectors like Maitreya and Viṣkambhin, lords of the ten grounds,
I, observing some precepts while breaking others, cry out in anguish from the depths of my heart seeking refuge. Upon merely glimpsing Vajrapāṇi,
The messengers of Yama and all malevolent forces
Flee terrified in all four directions
I take refuge in this supreme Vajra-holder. Having transgressed your sacred commands in the past,
Now seeing the great terrors,
I come to you for refuge;
Swiftly dispel these fears. Even one frightened by a minor ailment,
Should not disregard the physician's words;
How much more when afflicted by hundreds of diseases,
From the four afflictions and their four derivatives? When even one affliction like attachment or anger
Destroys all people dwelling in Jambudvīpa
What medicine that heals these mental poisons
Can be found in any direction, even in Brahma's realm The Omniscient Physician
Who extracts all thorns of suffering
One who contemplates not following His instructions
Is utterly deluded, a proper object of reproach If I must remain mindfully vigilant
Even at ordinary small precipices,
What need to mention the abyss of lower realms
Where one falls a thousand yojanas for endless time? Thinking 'I shall not die today,'
It is inappropriate to rest in comfort.
The time when I shall cease to exist
Will certainly come without fail. Who has given me fearlessness?
How could I escape this fate?
Since I will inevitably perish,
Why does my mind remain at ease? From all those pleasures I've experienced,
What lasting essence remains for me?
Yet fixated on such objects,
I've transgressed my guru's instructions. Abandoning this present life with all its trappings
Leaving behind my relatives and friends alike
When I must journey alone driven helplessly by karma
What use are all these loved ones and enemies to me From unwholesome actions suffering arises.
'How might I definitely escape from this?'
Day and night, constantly, I
Should think of this alone, as is proper. Due to my ignorance and fundamental confusion,
Whether natural misdeeds wrong for all beings by nature,
Or prescribed wrongs forbidden only to those under vows,
Whatever such negative actions I have committed. Standing directly before the Buddha protectors' omniscient gaze,
With joined palms, body trembling, fearful of lower realms' suffering,
I prostrate again and again, with profound remorse in every bow,
And confess all these misdeeds completely, turning away from each fault. May the guides—Buddhas and Bodhisattvas—acknowledge
my transgressions as true faults.
O Protectors, these actions are not virtuous;
Henceforth I shall never again commit such deeds. Thus concludes the second chapter entitled 'Confession of Negativities' Pāpadeśanā from the Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra. I joyfully rejoice in all virtuous deeds performed by sentient beings
That provide relief from the sufferings of lower realms in cyclic existence.
May those afflicted with suffering abide in happiness.
Though still bound by samsara's nature, I celebrate their merit with genuine delight. I rejoice in the virtues accumulated
As causes for the enlightenment of renunciants
I rejoice in the definite liberation
Of embodied beings from the sufferings of saṃsāra I rejoice in the enlightenment of the Buddhas, the protectors,
And in the progressive grounds attained by the Bodhisattvas.
In the mind that brings happiness to all sentient beings,
And the ocean of virtues arising from the generation of bodhicitta,
And in all actions performed for beings' benefit,
I rejoice. With palms joined in reverence and offering, I supplicate
All the Buddhas throughout every direction:
For beings who fall into suffering due to ignorance's darkness,
Please kindle the lamp of Dharma teachings. When the Conquerors wish to pass into nirvana,
With palms joined I offer this prayer:
May you not leave this world in blindness,
I beseech you to remain for countless eons. Having thus performed all these practices,
Through whatever virtue I have accumulated,
May all sentient beings'
Sufferings be completely dispelled. For as long as sentient beings are afflicted by illness,
Until they completely recover from their suffering,
May I become healing medicine and skilled physician,
And serve as their devoted attendant. By showering down exquisite food and drink with their hundred flavors,
I shall completely dispel the suffering of hunger and thirst.
During the intermediate kalpa of famine with its phases of scarcity,
May I myself become nourishment for all beings—an offering worthy of merit. For sentient beings impoverished and destitute,
May I become an inexhaustible treasure for them.
Manifesting as various necessities of every kind,
May I remain directly present before them. The body, likewise enjoyments,
And all virtues of the three times,
For the sake of accomplishing the welfare of all sentient beings,
Should be given away without miserliness. Through complete renunciation, nirvana is attained
My mind strives to accomplish this liberation
When everything must be relinquished simultaneously
Supreme is offering it to beings Since I have already given this body
To all sentient beings as they please,
Let them at all times kill me, criticize me,
Or beat me—I accept whatever they choose. Let them play with my body
Let them laugh, mock, and make it an object of ridicule
I have already given this body to all sentient beings
Why should I concern myself with protecting it? Let them engage in actions
That bring them well-being without causing harm
By the power of my dedication, may no being who focuses on me
Ever experience anything without purpose or benefit When sentient beings take me as their object of mind,
Whether with anger arising or devoted faith,
May that very mental state forever become
The cause fulfilling all their worldly and ultimate aims. Those who verbally criticize me
Those who inflict harm
Likewise those who mock
May all have the fortune of awakening. I am the protector for those without protection,
and the guide for travelers on the path.
For those wishing to cross over, I serve as a boat,
and I become both a ship and a bridge for them. For those who seek an island of refuge from life's turbulent waters, may I become an island
For those who desire a lamp in darkness to discern the righteous path, may I become a lamp
For those who need a dwelling place, may I become their shelter and resting place
I, for all embodied beings who require a servant
May I become a servant to all, fulfilling whatever they need The wish-fulfilling jewel and excellent vase
The accomplished knowledge mantra and great medicine
The wish-fulfilling tree
May I become for all embodied beings Like the great elements earth, water, fire, wind
And space that constantly pervades all,
May I become the foundation for immeasurable beings
The basis for their diverse needs and sustenance. Thus, to the vast realm of beings that extends
Throughout all ways to space's farthest reach,
Until all have attained perfect nirvana,
May I become their sustaining source indeed. Just as the ancient Sugatas,
Generated the awakening mind,
And trained in the bodhisattva's disciplines,
So I shall also follow in proper sequence. Just as the Buddhas before me, for the welfare of the world, I too shall generate this awakening mind of bodhicitta.
Likewise, I shall progressively train in all the disciplines
According to their proper sequence. Thus the wise bodhisattva
Having firmly grasped the awakening mind
To systematically prevent its decline
Should uplift the mind with joy. Today my life has become fruitful
I have excellently obtained this human existence
Today I have been born into the Buddha's family
And I have now become a child of the Buddha Now I must act in accordance with my lineage's ways,
Practicing diligently as Buddha's heirs have done,
So this flawless, noble lineage throughout all time
May never be stained or sullied by my misconduct. Just as a blind person might find a precious jewel
Among heaps of discarded refuse,
So too, by mere chance and through the Buddha's blessing,
This bodhicitta has arisen in me. This bodhicitta is the supreme nectar
That conquers the lord of death for all beings, bestowing deathlessness.
This awakening mind is indeed the inexhaustible treasure
That completely dispels both material and spiritual poverty for beings. This is the supreme medicine of enlightened mind
That pacifies all diseases of sentient beings.
For those exhausted from wandering the long pathways of saṃsāra,
This is the sheltering tree where all weary beings find true rest. A common platform for all beings.
It liberates them from the lower realms.
The moon of mind has risen
To dispel the torment of afflictions. The great sun that thoroughly uproots
the cataracts of ignorance in the world,

The butter essence that emerges
from churning the milk of the sublime Dharma. For wandering guests upon existence's path
Who yearn to taste the pleasures of delight,
This stands as supreme bliss, unfailing,
Satisfying all beings as great guests. Today, before all Protectors,
I have invited all sentient beings to the Sugata state of enlightenment
And, meanwhile, to be guests to happiness along the path.
May gods, asuras, and all others rejoice in this invitation! Thus concludes the third chapter entitled 'Thoroughly Adopting the Bodhicitta' Bodhicittaparigraha from 'Engaging in the Bodhisattva's Conduct' Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra. Thus, having firmly grasped bodhicitta with unwavering resolve,
The Child of the Victorious Ones who has taken the sacred vows
Must constantly remain vigilant without the slightest negligence,
And strive diligently never to transgress the bodhisattva trainings. Whatever is rashly begun
Or that which has been insufficiently investigated,
Even though one has firmly committed oneself to such action,
It is proper to thoroughly analyze whether to accept or reject it. That which the Buddhas and their spiritual heirs
Have thoroughly examined with their great wisdom,
And which I too have carefully analyzed through reasoning,
What excuse could there be to postpone its practice? If, after making this solemn vow,
I fail to fulfill it through practical actions,
Having deceived all these sentient beings,
What shall become of my destiny? Even for the most trivial of objects,
When one mentally resolves 'I shall give this,'
Yet fails to fulfill that intention,
It is taught that such a person becomes a hungry ghost. Having sincerely aspired to supreme unsurpassed bliss
And invited all beings as honored guests through bodhicitta intention
If I then deceive all wandering beings
How could I possibly journey to higher realms? How even those who abandon bodhicitta
Are still delivered to liberation.
This inconceivable workings of karma:
Only the Omniscient One truly knows. For a bodhisattva, this transgression stands as the gravest downfall above all others.
When one abandons the awakened resolve.
The foundation for benefiting all beings is destroyed.
This diminishes one's ability to help all sentient beings. Whoever, even for a moment, obstructs
The meritorious actions of this bodhisattva,
Will face limitless suffering in lower realms,
Having impeded one who works for beings' welfare. If destroying even one being's happiness
Causes one to fall from higher to lower realms,
Then what need to mention the karmic consequences
Of destroying the well-being of countless embodied beings throughout limitless space? Thus, by the power of transgressing through abandonment of bodhicitta
And subsequently by the power of regenerating this awakening mind,
One oscillates in saṃsāra, swinging between realms due to these actions,
And long delays attainment of the bodhisattva bhūmis. Therefore, as I have solemnly vowed,
I must respectfully fulfill my bodhisattva training.
If from today I fail to make diligent effort,
I will descend to lower realms. Innumerable Buddhas have come and gone
Who diligently sought the welfare of all sentient beings
Yet due to my own faults alone, I have not become
A suitable recipient of their healing ministrations. If I continue to act in this same manner still,
I shall experience again and again exactly thus:
Lower rebirths, disease, bondage in iron chains,
Cutting by swords, dismemberment by axes, and such sufferings. The advent of a Tathāgata in this world,
Faith in the Buddha's Tripitaka teachings, this precious human form with its eighteen freedoms and advantages,
And circumstances suitable for practicing virtue,
When will I ever again obtain these rare conditions? Though we enjoy this day free from illness.
With food to eat and no harm befalling us.
Life is momentary and deceptive.
This body, like something borrowed briefly. With such conduct as mine,
I will not again obtain a precious human body.
Without attaining a human form,
Only negative actions will prevail, with no opportunity for virtue. When, though endowed with leisure and fortune for virtuous action,
I fail to perform good deeds,
What shall I do when, in the lower realms' torment,
Completely deluded? For one who neither performs virtuous deeds
And instead accumulates evil actions,
Even after hundreds of millions of eons,
The very word 'fortunate rebirth' will not be heard. For this very reason the Blessed One declared
Human birth is exceedingly difficult to obtain
Even rarer than a blind turtle surfacing once every hundred years
Whose neck might chance upon a yoke's hole in the vast ocean From a single moment's sin,
One dwells in Avīci hell for an entire eon.
With sins accumulated since beginningless saṃsāra,
What need is there to mention the uncertainty of reaching higher realms? Merely by experiencing that suffering alone,
One will not attain liberation from the lower realms.
For while undergoing the ripening of previous deeds,
New evils arise—anger and malice perpetuating the cycle. Having obtained this precious human rebirth,
If I have not cultivated virtue,
There exists no greater deception than this,
Nor greater delusion than this ignorance. If, having realized this precious opportunity,
I later falter through delusion,
When the time of death arrives,
I shall be overcome with great sorrow. The unbearable fires of hell will burn

Therefore, it is entirely appropriate that I,
who have caused harm to beings, should now experience this suffering in return. Both the assailant's weapon and my own body
are equally causes of suffering.
When that person takes up a weapon against my body,
at whom should I be angry? This body, like a boil in human form,
Unbearable to touch, filled with suffering.
If I, blinded by craving, grasp onto it,
When harm comes to it, at whom should I be angry? Although I, like a foolish person, do not desire suffering
I am greedy for the very causes of suffering
When suffering arises due to my own faults
Why then do I become angry at others? Like hell's guardians and
Forests with razor-edged leaves,
These manifestations arise solely from my own karma.
At whom, then, should anger be directed? Prompted by my own past karma,
Those who harm me come into being.
By their harmful actions they go to the hell realms.
Have I not effectively destroyed these beings myself? By relying on these enemies,
Through patience, my negative karmas are purified.
Yet by directing their actions toward me,
They fall to hell for countless suffering. I am the one who harms these adversaries,
While they benefit me,
Why then, completely reversing the truth,
Do you, evil mind, erupt in anger? If I possess the quality of patience in my mind,
I will not fall into hell realms.
If I have protected myself through this practice,
What benefit has accrued here to those who caused harm? Even if I were to retaliate harm with harm,
Those beings would not be protected but would escalate in anger and negativity,
And my bodhisattva conduct would deteriorate,
Therefore, patience would be destroyed. The mind, being formless by nature,
Cannot be destroyed by anyone anywhere.
Yet due to its grasping attachment to the body,
The body is afflicted by sufferings. Contemptuous looks, harsh words,
And unpleasant speech,
Since these cannot harm your body,
Why then, O mind, do you become so angry? If others are displeased with me,
They will not devour me in this or future lives,
They cause me no actual harm,
Why should I object to this? Since others obstruct my gains through their contempt,
If I dislike this disrespect shown toward me,
My possessions will perish here when I depart empty-handed,
While the negative karma alone will firmly remain in my mindstream. Better for me to die today with virtue intact
Than prolong life through wrong livelihood's path
Even if I should dwell for ages in this realm
Death's suffering awaits, then karma's burden follows One who dreams of happiness for a hundred years and then awakens,
And another who experiences happiness for just a moment before awakening,
For both, when they awaken from their dreams,
Their happiness is equally gone, leaving no trace behind. For both who wake from dreams of joy,
That happiness never returns.
Just so at death's hour are alike—
Those who lived long and those who lived briefly. Though I acquire many riches
And enjoy abundant pleasures for a lengthy time,
Like one robbed by thieves, I must depart to the next life
Naked and empty-handed. If through wealth acquired I should live long,
And think, I'll cleanse past sins and merit gain,
Yet anger rises when my wealth pursuit meets wrongs,
Won't merit built through countless aeons drain? If the purpose for which I live
Is destroyed,
What use is such a life
That accomplishes nothing but negativity? If, because they cause harm to sentient beings,
You become angry at those who speak unpleasantly,
Then why do you not similarly
Become angry at those who speak unpleasantly about others? Since faith's absence depends on others,
You show patience to the faithless ones.
Since harsh words depend on afflictions' power,
Why not show patience to unpleasant speech? Toward Buddha images, stupas, and sacred Dharma texts,
Even those who mock and destroy them,
I should not generate anger or hatred,
For the Buddha and the Three Jewels cannot truly be harmed. When harm befalls your guru, relatives, and those dear to you.
Even toward those who injure your friends.
See how they act from conditions, as previously explained.
Recognizing their transformation by karma, dispel your anger completely. When embodied beings experience harm,
Whether from conscious beings or mindless things,
Why selectively blame those with consciousness?
Therefore, practice patience toward all harm. Some commit wrongdoings through delusion,
Some become angry through delusion.
Who among these can we declare faultless?
And whom can we truly pronounce guilty? Why did I previously create karma
That now causes others to harm me?
Since everything depends on karma,
Why should I harbor resentment? Having thus understood that suffering comes from karma,
I shall diligently strive in meritorious deeds,
So that all beings may, toward one another,
Develop minds of loving-kindness and friendship. Just as when a house is ablaze,
And fire travels to another dwelling,
Whatever grass or such it might ignite,
Is seized upon and cast away. When the mind becomes attached to objects of desire,
And anger's flames ignite,
Fearing merit will burn away,
One must abandon such attachment instantly. If a condemned man's hand is cut off
If he's set free, what could be wrong with that?
If through human trials
One escapes the torments of hell, what could be wrong with that? If today I cannot endure even this much suffering,
Then why do I not restrain anger,
Which is the cause
Of the torments of hell? For the sake of desires, I have endured burning and countless torments,
In the hells for thousands of eons through my craving and anger.
Yet through all this suffering, I have accomplished nothing for myself,
Nor have I achieved even the slightest benefit for others. This suffering is not so severe
And will accomplish purposes of great value
In suffering that removes the afflictions of beings
One should feel nothing but joy When others praise those rich in virtues
Even your rivals—and find joy thereby
Why, O mind, will you not praise them too
And share this mudita the Buddhas praise? This joyful happiness from praising others' qualities
Is a blameless source of true bliss
Approved by those endowed with noble qualities
And supreme in attracting others to your spiritual circle If thinking, 'This will make my enemy happy.'
You refuse them joy through envy's grip.
Then by withholding wages and gifts from servants.
You destroy both visible and future karmic benefits. When your own qualities are being praised,
You desire others to share in this happiness too.
When others' qualities are being praised,
You refuse even your own happiness in doing so. All sentient beings desire happiness,
Having generated bodhicitta,
When sentient beings find happiness by themselves,
Why then do you become angry? You aspire for beings to attain Buddhahood,
Worthy of veneration in all three worlds.
Yet seeing them receive even modest respect,
Why do you burn with such jealousy toward them? One who you must nourish and support
When they provide for themselves they give to you
Yet when a dependent finds their own livelihood
Instead of rejoicing do you grow angry If one does not wish even worldly gain for beings,
Yet claims to desire their enlightenment,
How can bodhicitta possibly exist
In one who burns with jealousy at others' prosperity? Whether they received from that patron,
Or remained within the donor's home,
If you possess none of these things,
Why care what was given or not given? Why through jealousy would you abandon merit and faithful patrons
Or discard your own virtuous qualities that naturally attract offerings
When others receive gains but you fail to maintain these worthy causes
Tell me for what reason would you not be angry with yourself Not only do you fail to feel remorse for the negative actions you have committed,
But you even desire to compete with
Others who have accumulated merit
Through proper conduct.
End of the second volume. If your enemy suffers misfortune,
What benefit could you derive from rejoicing?
Your mere wishful thinking and desires
Cannot become a cause of their harm. Even if, by your will, that suffering befalls your enemy,
What joy could this possibly bring to you?
And if you claim your desires are fulfilled by this,
What greater ruin exists than this hatred? This terrible hook of malice, cast by the fishermen of afflictions.
Is indeed an unbearable barb.
When caught by it, in the cauldrons of hell.
The hell guardians will surely boil one. Praise, fame, and honorific treatment do not generate merit.
Praise, fame, and honorific treatment do not increase longevity.
Praise, fame, and honorific treatment do not enhance my strength, nor prevent illness.
Praise, fame, and honorific treatment do not bring physical comfort to my body. If I were truly wise about my own self-interest
What benefit would there be for me in praise and fame

Then I might as well resort to alcohol, gambling, ornaments and the like For the sake of fame, wealth is given away,

Children wail in anguished grief
Likewise when praise and fame diminish
The mind behaves just like a child. Since sound itself possesses no consciousness,
It cannot possibly conceive of praising me.
'Others find joy in praising me'—a mere illusion;
How could their pleasure, forever theirs alone, truly benefit me? Whether it concerns others or myself,
what benefit does another's joy bring to me?
That joy and happiness belongs solely to them;
I cannot obtain even the slightest portion of it. If I am happy because of another's happiness,
Then I should feel this same joy for all beings,
Why then, when others experience happiness,
Am I not happy for them? Therefore, when one thinks 'I am being praised,'
Joy arises within oneself;
Yet this too is baseless—mere sound without substance;
It is nothing but childish behavior, binding one to cyclic suffering. Praise and such things cause me to become distracted;
They destroy any disillusionment with saṃsāra I might have;
They breed jealousy toward those endowed with good qualities;
They destroy all excellence and prosperity. Therefore, those who stand before me
to destroy my praise and such worldly things
are they not truly engaged in my protection
guarding me from falling into the realms of suffering? I seek liberation as my aim.
I need not be bound by gain and praise.
Those who free me from my bondage,
How could I feel anger toward them? I desire to enter suffering.
Just as blessed by the Buddha.
Those who become gates barring my passage.
How could I feel anger toward them? This person obstructs my merit.
Even toward such, anger is not fitting.
No austerity equals patience's worth.
Through enemies, should I not firmly dwell therein. If I, due to my own faults, do not practice patience
Toward those who cause me harm,
Then when the cause of merit stands readily before me,
I alone am creating the obstacle to my spiritual progress. That which cannot arise without something,
and which exists when that thing is present—
that very thing is its cause.
How then can it be called an obstacle? When the mendicant arrives at the proper time,
He is not an obstacle but the very cause that enables giving.
When those who confer ordination appear,
They are not impediments but essential causes of the monastic path. In this world beggars are plentiful indeed
While those who harm rare
For when I cause no offense to others first
Rarely does anyone arise to harm me without cause Therefore, like a treasure appearing in one's home
Without having been acquired through any labor,
Since they serve as companions in my bodhisattva practice,
I should cherish my enemies as supporters of my path. Since both this foe and I have accomplished patience together
Therefore this fruit of patience
Must first be offered to this very adversary
For they are the primary cause of patience itself If you say, 'The enemy is not worthy of veneration
because he has no intention to help establish patience,'
then why do you venerate the sublime Dharma?
Just like the enemy, the Dharma too can function as a cause for spiritual accomplishment, yet it also lacks any conscious intention. If an enemy with harmful intent
Is not worthy of veneration, as you say,
Then how could I cultivate the perfection of patience
When faced with one who, like a physician, strives only for my benefit? Therefore, since patience arises
In dependence upon that very ill-intentioned person,
That same one, being the cause of patience,
Should be venerated just like the sacred Dharma. Therefore, the Sage has taught: 'Sentient beings' field and
Victorious Ones' field.'
By pleasing both, many have
Thus crossed to perfection's abundant shore. From sentient beings and Victorious Ones alike,
The sublime qualities of Buddhahood equally arise in us.
Why then do we revere the Victors
But not sentient beings—what manner of reasoning is this? The greatness of intention is not inherent in itself
But is established by its results leading to Buddhahood
Similarly sentient beings possess the potential for enlightenment
Therefore they are equal to Buddhas as fields of merit When offerings are made to one possessing loving-kindness meditation,
This merit stems from the profound greatness of sentient beings themselves.
Whatever merit arises from devotion and faith in the Buddha,
That likewise manifests from the Buddha's own greatness. Through inherent Buddha-nature that fulfills dharma qualities,
Thus they are considered equal in this regard.
Yet none can match the Buddhas
With their infinite ocean of excellences. One who possesses the unique collection of supreme qualities.
Even a tiny fraction of qualities seen in someone.
For the purpose of honoring such a being.
Even offering the three realms would be insufficient. The portion of causes for the supreme Buddha-dharma's arising
Exists within all sentient beings as well.
For this reason alone, in accordance with this aspect,
Sentient beings should properly be objects of veneration. Furthermore, to those who have become our true friends without pretense,
Who bestow immeasurable benefits upon all beings,
Other than pleasing sentient beings,
What greater way could there be to repay their kindness. Those for whose sake the Sage would sacrifice his body and enter the Avīci hell,
to benefit them is to repay his kindness.
Therefore, even toward those who cause great harm,
one should perform only excellent deeds in all circumstances. Since even my own Lord himself
Disregards even his own body for others' sake,
How could I, in my delusion, show pride
Rather than adopt a servant's nature toward these various masters. When the happiness of sentient beings brings joy to the Lords of Sages,
And when harm to these beings causes the Perfect Ones to feel displeasure,
By bringing joy to these beings, one makes the supreme offering that pleases all Lords of Sages.
By causing harm to these beings, one has precisely and equivalently harmed the Sages themselves. Just as one whose body is ablaze on all sides
Cannot find joy in any pleasures however desirable,
So too when harm is done to sentient beings,
The greatly compassionate ones cannot possibly be pleased. Therefore, I who have harmed beings,
And thus displeased all those of great compassion,
Today I openly confess each sin individually,
For all displeasure caused, I beseech the Mighty Sages for patience. To please the Tathagatas,
From this day forward, I firmly commit myself to becoming a servant of the world.
Whether the masses strike me on the crown of my head with their feet,
Or even kill me, I shall not be provoked; may the Protector of the World be pleased. All beings in this world have been made their own by those whose nature is compassion.
There is absolutely no doubt about this.
Indeed, these beings who appear in the form of sentient beings are none other than the protectors themselves.
Why then should one not show reverence to them? This practice of patient endurance and showing respect toward beings truly pleases the Tathagatas Buddhas.
This same practice accomplishes one's own purpose by accumulating merit.
This patience and kindness toward beings dispels worldly suffering by enabling them to engage in virtuous actions.
Therefore, I shall always diligently practice these three types of patience, pleasing all beings. Just as a royal official may oppress the common people, the far-sighted multitude, who discern future consequences, though fully capable, wisely choose not to retaliate. Since none from royal ranks acts alone,
The king's power serves as their strength and force.
Likewise, even the feeblest wrongdoer
Should never be despised, harmed, or ignored. Thus the guardians of hell and
Those with compassion are their forces.
Just like commoners to a fierce king,
One should please all sentient beings. What harm can an angry king truly inflict, |
Can he cause the torments of hell, |
That one will experience in future lives, |
From causing distress to sentient beings. | Even if a king is thoroughly pleased,
By delighting sentient beings,
That which is attained—
No king can bestow Buddhahood itself. That comes from pleasing sentient beings through patient care and benefit;
Let alone future Buddhahood, why do you not see even in this very life
The prosperity that becomes a foundation for qualities, fame that spreads widely, and happiness arising from benefiting all? While wandering in saṃsāra, through patience one attains beauty with complete faculties and form,
Freedom from illness, great renown, and abiding happiness,
An extremely long life with sustained well-being,
And the abundant prosperity of a universal monarch establishing virtue. From the Bodhicaryāvatāra Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life, this is the sixth chapter entitled 'Teaching on Patience' Kṣānti-pāramitā. Thus endowed with patience, one should strive with diligence
For upon diligence, enlightenment rests as if in one's palm
Just as without wind there can be no movement
Without diligence, neither merit nor wisdom can arise Diligence is enthusiasm toward virtue.
Let me explain its contrary aspects.
Laziness is attachment to idleness and engagement in negative pursuits.

And the craving that seeks refuge in sleep
From not being disheartened by saṃsāra's suffering
Laziness arises Ensnared by the net of afflictions,
And fallen into the trap of birth,
You have entered the jaws of the Lord of Death.
Why do you still not recognize this and act? Do you not see your own kind
Being slain, one after another?
Yet still you sink into sleep

Gather well the twin accumulations while you still can
Though at the Lord of Death's approach you cast off sloth
What provisions for the journey can you secure when time has run out This task remains unbegun though conceived in mind,
That one barely started, this half-complete stands,
When suddenly the Lord of Death arrives,

What need is there even to speak of the inconceivable
Torments of hell that await those who commit negative actions. When touched by hot water,

The delicate ones who suffer countless harms

Alas! They are crushed by sufferings Having reached the vessel of human birth with its freedoms and advantages,
Cross over the great river of suffering of the three realms of existence.

Boundless source of bliss,

I must never fall into discouragement.
For the Tathāgata speaks only truth.

I discern what helps and harms

Without discerning between heavy and light,

Is limited in measure;
Like pain from surgery removing a piercing thorn,

Therefore, to eliminate the numerous sufferings of the three realms of samsara,
One should endure minor discomforts of spiritual practice and austerities. The Supreme Physician does not employ
Such harsh treatments as bloodletting or cauterization;
Through exceedingly gentle methods instead,
He heals immeasurable great diseases. At first, the Guide instructs those who struggle
To practice giving vegetables and simple gifts.
Through steady practice, mental resistance fades,

Then in giving away one's flesh and so forth,
What difficulty indeed could there be? The Bodhisattva feels no suffering, having abandoned negative deeds.
And knows no mental distress, having realized selflessness.
For it is wrong conceptualization that clings to 'I' and 'mine'.
And negative actions that bring affliction to both mind and body. Through merit, the body experiences comfort,
Through wisdom, the mind finds happiness.
Though they remain in saṃsāra for the benefit of others,

Mounted on the steed of bodhicitta

Generate aspiration—root from which these powers spring—by contemplating both the suffering that non-virtue brings

Through devotion, confident resolve,

The place of immeasurable suffering,

There, by their merit,

Having begun, cultivate the confidence to persevere to completion First, one should carefully examine one's resources and capabilities.
Based on this assessment, one should decide whether to undertake the action or not.

Non-virtuous actions and suffering will multiply
Other endeavors and their time of fruition
Will degrade in quality and remain unaccomplished One should cultivate noble confidence in three domains.
Actions, afflictions, and one's capacity to overcome them.
Thinking, 'I alone must accomplish this.'
This constitutes the proper pride in action. This world, enslaved by afflictions, is incapable
Of accomplishing even its own aims.
Since beings cannot practice virtue as I can,
Therefore I myself shall undertake this task. When others perform lowly tasks,

If my mind becomes weak and feeble,

By none shall I be overcome

Others fall to pride's power. Filled with the affliction of pride

Even in human rebirth, one's celebrations are destroyed
Becoming a servant subsisting on others' food
A fool like a pig, unsightly as a frog, weakly emaciated Everywhere one becomes despised.
Those ascetics practicing austerities, yet puffed up with pride.

Who bear the antidote-pride to vanquish the enemy of afflictive pride

Bestow upon all sentient beings exactly as they wish the fruit of victory: complete enlightenment. When dwelling amidst conditions that trigger afflictions
Apply antidotes with a thousandfold intensity
Like a lion untroubled by packs of smaller beasts

As one protects the eye,
So too when facing hardship,
One should never fall under the power of afflictions. I would rather be burned and killed,

But in no way whatsoever
Will I bow to afflictions as my enemies.
Likewise, in all circumstances,

So should bodhisattvas be drawn to their virtuous deeds
Devoted to these actions never satisfied
Yet finding inherent happiness in this spiritual joy Though actions are performed for the sake of happiness,
Whether they will bring happiness remains uncertain,
For bodhisattvas whose virtuous deeds themselves become sources of immediate and lasting joy,

Just as an elephant scorched by midday heat,
When meeting a lake, plunges in,
One should likewise engage in these deeds. When strength is depleted through spiritual exertion,
Set it aside with joy, intending to resume when restored.
Though a practice may be well accomplished,

Defend against the blows of afflictions with vigilance,
While striking forcefully at these enemy passions,

A sword that has fallen,

Spreads throughout the entire body,
Likewise, when afflictions find an opening,

Watched by men with drawn swords standing nearby;
Who proceeds with intense focus, fearing death should it spill;

When finding a serpent coiled upon one's lap,
So too when drowsiness and sloth arise,
One should swiftly dispel them. For each and every fault that arises,
I shall thoroughly reproach myself and,
Reflecting long on past harmful outcomes

With this cause as motivation, one should seek
Either association with virtuous Mahāyāna teachers
or engagement in appropriate spiritual activities. To ensure one's virtuous deeds have power from the beginning,
One should recall the teachings on mindfulness,

Coming and going movements,

Place the mind in meditative concentration. One
Whose mind is completely distracted

Distractions cannot possibly arise;

Therefore, having completely abandoned these inner and outer attachments,
The discerning sage should contemplate thus. Understanding that insight, when endowed with calm abiding,
Thoroughly destroys the afflictions,
First seek calm abiding,
Which is accomplished through genuine delight in isolated places, free from attachment to worldly concerns. What impermanent being could rightfully form attachment to that which is impermanent?
Through such attachment, across thousands of births,
One will find neither joy nor their beloved again. Not seeing the desired object, one finds no joy.
The mind cannot rest in meditative concentration.
Even upon seeing it, one remains unsatisfied.
Just as before, tormented by craving's thirst. If one becomes attached to sentient beings,
it completely obscures one from seeing reality as it truly is.
Such attachment destroys the mind of renunciation
and ultimately leads to being tormented by grief. By obsessing over these transient friends,
This precious human life wastes away in vain.
Through attachment to impermanent companions,
The eternal Dharma leading to supreme liberation is destroyed. If one engages with ordinary beings bāla through body, speech, and mind,
One will certainly descend to the lower realms of existence.
When they lead one away from the noble lineage's path of few desires, contentment, and renunciation,
What benefit is there in relying on such unwise beings? In an instant they become friends,
In an instant they become enemies.
With fickle minds, they grow angry at what should bring joy and virtue—
These childish, ordinary beings are impossible to please. When I speak what benefits them in dharma they respond with anger
They actively create obstacles to turn me away from virtuous deeds that bring benefit
If I do not heed their discouraging words and distractions
Angered at being ignored these childish beings accumulate karma for unfortunate rebirths From the superior, one feels jealousy; with equals, one competes in rivalry.
Towards the inferior, one displays pride; when praised, one becomes arrogant.
When criticized with unpleasant words, anger arises.
When will one ever obtain benefit from childish people? When associating with the childish—unless one is a noble being—
Self-praise, disparagement of others,
And talk that fosters attachment to cyclic existence—
From such company, non-virtue will certainly emerge. Thus, associating with childish persons
Only leads to mutual destruction
They have not acted for my spiritual benefit
Nor shall I become beneficial to them From childish people—friends and kin—flee far away
If you must meet them, please them briefly with kind speech
Avoid developing any deep familiarity
Remain neutral and detached, like meeting strangers anew. Like a bee taking honey from flowers without harm
I shall extract merely the essence of Dharma
Maintaining distance as if meeting all for the first time
I shall dwell everywhere without becoming familiar. I have gained many possessions and honors
And many people are drawn to me with affection
If I harbor such conceited pride
After death, fear of the hell realms will arise Wherever the deluded mind, bound by self-clinging,
Becomes attached to objects of pleasure and worldly gain,
Those very attachments, combined and multiplied thousandfold,
Rise up like an awakening old bear as intense suffering. Therefore the wise should not become attached.
From attachment arises fear.
Since these things will by their nature be abandoned.
Establish your mind firmly and thoroughly investigate. Many have gained wealth and possessions,
And though fame and praise have come about,
With these accumulations of riches and renown,
There is no certainty where one will go. If others exist who criticize me,
What reason is there to rejoice in praise?
If others exist who praise me,
What reason is there to be troubled by criticism? Sentient beings with diverse karmic dispositions,
cannot be pleased even by the Victorious Buddhas,
how much less by an inferior ignorant one like myself,
therefore, abandon all concern with worldly thoughts. Childish beings disparage those lacking possessions
And speak ill of those who have wealth
By nature difficult to associate with
How could joy arise from such beings Since childish persons are incapable of joy
Unless it serves their self-interest
The Tathagatas have proclaimed
'No childish person can truly be anyone's friend.' In the forest, wild animals, birds,
And trees never utter unpleasant words.
When will I dwell with these pleasant companions,
Among whom life is peaceful? In caves or empty temples
Dwelling at the foot of a tree
When will I no longer look backward
Becoming completely free from attachment When will I dwell in places that no one claims as their own,
In naturally spacious and open areas,
Moving about freely at will without attachment -
When will I dwell? Having just a begging bowl and the like
Wearing clothes that no one would steal
Even without concealing this body
When will I become one who dwells without fear? Having gone to the charnel ground,
When shall I equalize my own body
With the skeletal remains of others,
Recognizing both as equally subject to destruction? This very body of mine
Will certainly become so putrid
That even jackals repelled by its stench
Would not dare approach it. Even this single body of mine
Its bones, born together as inseparable parts
Will fragment and scatter in separate ways.
What need to mention other beloved ones
Who've converged through separate karmic conditions? Alone one is born into this world
And in absolute solitude one dies
Since none can bear another's burden of suffering
What purpose do dear ones serve who create obstacles to virtue. As travelers on journeys seize and leave each dwelling place,
Just as they hold onto their stopping places along the way,
Likewise, those who travel the path of existence,
Fully grasp and cling to each birthplace. While the world laments with tearful eyes,
As long as the four pallbearers,
Have not yet lifted the body from its place,
Until then, retreat to the forest. Without attachments or enmities,
Dwelling alone with just this body in a secluded hermitage,
Having already considered oneself dead to the world,
When one actually dies, there is no cause for others to lament. In mountain solitude, no attendants near.
Cause sorrow or distress through grieving here.
None disturb one's Buddha recollection.
Or Dharma thoughts upon death's liberation. Therefore, I shall dwell alone in delightful solitude
Effortless, conducive to peace, and bringing joy
Where all distractions are naturally pacified
Such solitude I shall always cultivate Abandoning all worldly thoughts,
With single-pointed attention examining only my own mind,
I shall strive for the meditative equipoise of mind,
And for its discipline, cultivating both aspects of bodhicitta. In this world and the beyond,
Desires indeed produce calamities.
Here, they cause killing, binding, and severing;
Beyond, they generate hell, hungry ghost, and animal realms. For whose sake, in the past, male and female messengers.
Making numerous supplications with joined palms.
For whose sake, without concern for grave sins or ill reputation.
Without hesitation risking dangers and exhausting resources. Though I plunge myself into gravest dangers,
And exhaust my wealth in wasteful spending,
Those very women's bodies I embrace with passion,
Are but flesh-wrapped bones yielding false, fleeting joy. Female bodies are but skeletons nothing more
Neither independent nor constituting a self
Though you intensely desire and thoroughly cling to them
Why not proceed to nirvana That face, when lifted with effort, yet downcast through shyness.
Whether previously seen or unseen before marriage.
Now veiled with cloth according to regional custom.
Will one day be unveiled by vultures in the charnel ground. Behold that face which once inflamed your passion
Now plainly exposed where once it shyly turned away
See how the vultures have laid bare what you jealously guarded
Why do you now flee in terror from what you once claimed as yours? That which you jealously guarded from even others' gazes.
That body you so completely protected.
Now when it is being consumed by scavengers.
Why, O possessive one, do you not protect it. Seeing this mound of flesh,
Devoured by vultures and other creatures,
Food for others adorned with flower
Garlands, sandalwood and ornaments. You tremble at a motionless skeleton,
Mere bones seen in the charnel ground;
Yet why not fear when these same bones stir,
Animated by inner winds, like a vetāla-possessed corpse you cherish? If attachment persists even for what is covered,
Why would the same uncovered not be desired?
If it serves no purpose in its natural state,
Why then is this covered form caressed? From a single source of food
Feces and saliva emerge;
While you find feces repulsive,
Why do you delight in saliva? Soft as cotton to the touch,
Rejecting pillows with delight,
Claiming: 'They do not ooze with foul smell'—
Those filled with desire, deluded by impurity. The lustful, wicked, and deluded ones,
touch cotton, feeling its softness,
saying, 'One cannot engage in sexual intercourse with this,'
they become angry at it. If you have no passion for the impure,
This is merely a skeletal cage bound together by tendons,
Smeared with the muddy filth of flesh.
Why then do you embrace another person in your lap? You yourself contain many impurities
Yet constantly enjoy this very vessel of filth
And toward other sacks of impurity
You crave and desire with longing for impurity I am fond of this flesh,
And wish to see and touch it eagerly.
If flesh by nature lacks consciousness,
Why do you not desire corpse-flesh equally? The mind that you desire,
Cannot be touched nor seen.
What can be touched is not consciousness.
What purpose does meaningless embracing serve? That you see not another's body as impure
No wonder in that
But that you perceive not your own body's manifest filth
That truly is astonishing Having abandoned the young lotus flower
that blossoms in the cloudless sun's rays,
why would one whose mind is fixated on impurity
find it reasonable to delight in a mere cage of filth? If you refuse to touch ground
That is defiled by impurities,
How then can you desire to touch
The body from which they emerge? If you claim no attachment to impurity,
That body, born from an impure field,
Was developed from seed,
Why do you embrace another in your lap? You reject the tiny impure worm born of filth.
Too foul for your desire.
Yet eagerly crave the body—vessel of many impurities.
Itself a product of the same defilement you despise. You do not feel revulsion for your own impure body.
Not only that, but moreover,
You, an impure vessel, toward the impure,
With craving, desire others as well. Even pleasant substances like camphor and other delights,
Rice dishes and savory vegetables too,
When put in the mouth, then removed and discarded,
Render even the ground impure and defiled. If even this impure body, though directly perceived,
You still doubt its nature,
Then observe other corpses cast in charnel grounds
The impure remains that reveal truth beyond question. When the skin is peeled away,
Great terror arises,
Yet knowing this truth about the body,
How can desire repeatedly arise? The fragrance applied upon the body
Comes from sandalwood and such, not from itself.
Why then are you attached to others' bodies
For a scent that truly belongs elsewhere? Since the body is naturally foul-smelling,
Would it not be better to remain unattached to it?
Worldly people with their meaningless cravings,
Why do they anoint it with external fragrances? What of fragrant sandalwood's sweetness
Has truly come to this inherently foul body?
Why are beings drawn to others through scents
Deliberately applied to incite attachment? If with long hair and nails, teeth blackened and yellowish-gray,
The naked body reeking with filth and mud's foul stench,
In its natural state appears demon-like and terrifying—
Why do we meticulously polish this weapon that only harms ourselves? Like weapons that inflict self-harm when polished,
Why labor to cleanse and adorn this form?
Through efforts born of delusion,
Madmen fill this earth with chaos. Having seen mere skeletons in the cremation ground
You turn away with disgust and revulsion
Yet do you delight in the village cremation ground
Filled with moving skeletons animated by mind and wind Thus, even this impure female form cannot be obtained without payment.
Gold, horses, or lesser means are required for the price.
The toil of pursuing that purpose exhausts one completely.
Leading to sufferings in hell and other such realms. In childhood, one cannot gather wealth
In youth, without such wealth, how can one find pleasure
If life is wasted in travel and trade merely accumulating riches
What use are sensual desires when old age renders them impossible Some evil men, consumed by sensual desires,
Exhausted from toiling the entire day,
Return home with depleted bodies,
And lie like corpses in sleep. Some tormented by journeys for trade or plunder
Suffer both mental anguish and physical pain in distant lands
Though yearning for their children and wives denied even basic touch
For years they cannot glimpse these beloved ones despite their longing Those deluded by desires sell themselves or their kin for promised gains,
Yet obtaining nothing, their precious human birth is wasted in vain,
Driven helplessly by the winds of others' karma,
Creating present suffering and future obstacles to liberation. Some sell their own bodies,
And powerlessly are controlled by others.
Their wives, when children are born,
Must give birth beneath trees in wilderness. Fools deceived by desire, believing they'll sustain their lives;
Though fearing death, enter battles, for profit's sake they submit to servitude. Some, driven by sensual desires like moths to flames, have their bodies cut apart.
Others who transgress through craving are impaled on stakes as royal punishment, like deer lured by sounds.
Some are pierced by short spears and weapons, caught by attachment as fish by hooks.
While others burn in great fires, struggling with wealth—its accumulation, protection, and loss—sinking deeper like elephants in mud. Through the anguish of acquiring, guarding, and losing wealth,
Know it as an endless source of suffering in this life and beyond.
Those whose minds are scattered by attachment to possessions
Have no opportunity for liberation from samsara's torments. For those consumed by sensual desires
Countless faults abound while pleasures remain fleeting
Like oxen pulling carts
Snatching mere mouthfuls of grass. For the sake of trivial pleasures, which even animals can readily obtain,
This precious human life with leisures and endowments, so rare to find,
Is squandered by those afflicted
By their karmic confusion. Desires, which inevitably perish,
Lead to falls through hell and lower realms;
Because they yield no lasting value,
All this endless toil exhausts through time. With a mere fraction of that effort,
One could attain the state of Buddhahood.
Those bound by desires pursue awakening practices,
Yet find great suffering and no enlightenment. When one contemplates the torments of hell and lower realms,
Neither weapons, poison, fire, precipices,
Nor enemies can serve
As worthy comparisons to sense desires. Thus, having grown weary of desires,
Cultivate joy in solitude.
Empty of conflict and afflictions,
In peaceful forest lands. The blessed bodhisattvas pace upon wide stone terraces of delightful mansions.
Cooled by moonlight and sandalwood more sublime than any royal comfort.
Silent, soothing forest breezes gently caress without disturbance.
They walk in meditation, contemplating ways to benefit all limitless beings. In empty houses, beneath trees, or in caves,
One stays wherever and however long desired.
Freed from the suffering of possessing and protecting belongings,
One moves about independently, without expectations from others, exactly as one wishes. One moves freely without attachment
Bound to no one high or low friend or foe
The bliss of contentment with life simple necessities
Even Indra lord of gods finds such happiness hard to attain Through these various forms of solitude,
By thoroughly contemplating the qualities of seclusion,
With discursive thoughts pacified,
One should develop the awakening mind. Equality of self and others,
First, diligently practice meditation.
Since happiness and suffering are equal,
Protect all just as you would yourself. Just as one body with its many parts like hands
Is protected as a single entity, though merely parts conventionally labeled as one
Similarly, though beings in the world appear diverse
All share in suffering and joy alike—all should be regarded as oneself. Though my suffering does not afflict the bodies of others,
That very same suffering is unbearable to me,
Due to my attachment to myself as 'I',
This pattern, through training, can extend my concern to all beings. Similarly, although the suffering of others does not directly befall me in experience,
Nevertheless, that suffering becomes my own suffering;
Through clinging to others as self,
It becomes unbearable. I shall eliminate the suffering of others,
For it is suffering just like my own suffering.
I shall benefit others as I would myself,
For they are sentient beings, just as I am one. When both myself and others equally desire happiness,
what difference is there between myself and others?
For what reason
should I strive for happiness for myself alone? When suffering is equally unwelcome
To myself and others alike
What special distinction exists between us
That I protect myself but not others If I don't protect others from suffering
Because their pain doesn't harm me now,
Then who will protect me from future suffering
That likewise doesn't afflict me at present? The thought 'I will experience that suffering'
Is indeed a mistaken conceptualization.
For the one who dies is a different entity,
And the one who is born is likewise different. When one's suffering must be protected by oneself,
The foot's suffering should not concern the hand.
Since their pains are distinct,
Why then does the hand protect the foot? If it's argued, 'Though unreasonable, one still acts
Due to ingrained self-grasping'—
Whether about self or other—continuums or collections—
Must be abandoned according to one's capacity. Continuum and collection like garlands and armies
Are illusory designations with no inherent existence
Since the one who would experience suffering does not truly exist
Who then could possibly claim this suffering as their own? All suffering has no owner,
Without distinction whatsoever.
Because it is suffering, it should be eliminated.
What purpose does certainty serve here? If suffering should be eliminated, why speak of 'all beings'?
This itself is beyond dispute.
If elimination is proper, then all suffering should cease;
If not, then just like other sentient beings, neither should mine. Since compassion makes one bear sufferings,
Why deliberately cultivate such pain?
When contemplating the agonies of beings,
How can compassion's suffering be too great? If through one person's suffering

Then one endowed with loving-kindness should indeed
Willingly accept that suffering for self and others. Therefore, Supuṣpacandra Flower-Moon-Beautiful,
Although foreseeing the king would take his life,
Did not seek to escape his own suffering,
To liberate countless beings from their pain. Having thus habituated their mindstream,
Those who delight in pacifying others' suffering,
Like swans entering a lotus lake,
Will enter even Avīci hell without anguish. When sentient beings are being liberated,
Those oceans of immense joy arise.
Is this alone not entirely sufficient?
What use is flavorless liberation for oneself? Therefore, even when working for others' benefit,
Neither pride nor wonder arises in one's mind;
With joy directed solely toward others' welfare,
One expects no fruits of karmic ripening for oneself. Therefore, just as I protect myself
From even the slightest unpleasant words,
So too for others I shall cultivate
A mind of protection and compassion. Just as through habituation, regarding

Though no real entity exists there,

just as one identifies with a body formed from parents' elements despite its lack of inherent selfhood
to establish one's own body as belonging to others
is indeed not difficult Having recognized oneself as flawed
And others as oceans of virtues that bring every happiness
One should cultivate the complete abandonment of self-clinging
And the thorough embracing of others through systematic exchange practice Just as hands and other limbs
Are considered parts of one's body,
Likewise, as limbs of the world,

In this body that inherently lacks a self,
Similarly, toward other sentient beings as well,
Why wouldn't the same sense of selfhood arise through habituation? Thus, even when working for others' benefit
No pride or wonder arises through habituation
Just as after feeding oneself

From even the slightest harm like unkind words,
In the same way, toward all beings,

With great compassion for all beings,
To dispel the fears of cyclic existence,
Blessed even his own name with sacred power. One should not turn away from difficult spiritual practices.
For through the power of prolonged habituation.
Those very practices whose names once caused terror when heard.
Will, when absent, become a source of unhappiness. Whoever wishes swiftly to protect
Oneself and all sentient beings
Should practice that supreme secret,
The exchange of self and other. When to this body, deeply cherished through attachment
Even tiny threats like gnats and snakes cause fearful dread
This form that breeds all fears now and in future lives
What wise one would not view it as a foe, and self for other trade Whoever, seeking remedies for bodily weakness, hunger, thirst, and other ailments,
Kills birds, fish, and wild animals for food and personal needs,

this body?
Who would not view it as an enemy,
