This self-concerned thinking is the way of demons.
'If I enjoy, what shall I have to give?'—
This mindset of prioritizing others is the dharma of gods. One who harms others for selfish gain
Will be tormented in hell and other lower realms
One who sacrifices oneself for others' sake
Will attain all excellent prosperities. Through desire to elevate oneself above others
One falls to lower realms, becomes degraded and foolish
When this very desire for elevation is directed toward others instead
One attains higher rebirth and receives perfect honor and service When one commands others for one's own purpose,
One experiences the ripened result as servant, slave, and alike in future lives.
When one dedicates oneself for others' purpose,
One experiences the result as master, lord, and alike. Whatever happiness exists in the world,
All of it arises from desiring others' well-being.
Whatever suffering exists in the world,
All of it arises from desiring one's own well-being. What need is there for many words?
The childish who pursue only their own benefit,
And the sage who, acting solely for others' welfare,
Observe this crucial difference between these two. Without truly practicing exchanging
One's happiness for others' suffering,
Neither is Buddhahood ever attainable,
Nor can happiness be found within cyclic existence. Setting aside the matter of future lives,
when servants, cherishing themselves, neglect their work,
And masters, from self-interest, withhold fair payment,
Even the objectives of this present life cannot be accomplished. Achieving happiness seen and unseen,
Forsaking all perfect well-being and blissful prosperity,
Through causing suffering to others,
Deluded beings take upon themselves unbearable anguish. Whatever harms exist in this world,
And however many fears and sufferings there may be,
All these arise from grasping at a self,
What purpose, then, does this great demon serve for me? Without completely abandoning self-grasping
One cannot eliminate the suffering
Just as without discarding fire

I give myself fully to other beings

o mind firmly establish this understanding
except for serving all beings' welfare
you must think of nothing else from now on It is not proper to use eyes and other faculties

Whatever you see on your body,
Take these away from yourself,

And similarly having placed others in the position of oneself
With a mind free from conceptual elaboration
Meditate on jealousy, competitiveness, and pride. That one is honored, not I;

This one indeed is renowned as great in the world,

I must actively cultivate the virtues of my inherent buddha-nature.

I willingly accept whatever hardships this treatment brings If I am not one to be healed by this bodhisattva,

True worth lies in qualities that benefit others. Standing at the precipice of lower realms,
They show no compassion for beings,

One seeks to exceed them for personal superiority
Striving to secure material gain and veneration

Become evident to the entire world

I shall receive honor, not this person.
Today I have gained excellent rewards.
I shall be respected, not this one. For those who have committed harmful deeds

And the target of criticism from every direction This miserable affliction kleśa of pride within me
Makes me perceive others as my competitors. Am I comparing myself based on

Proclaimed and renowned throughout all realms,
With hair bristling and heart delighted,

For in hundreds of ways throughout countless cycles
It has brought me nothing but misery while wandering in saṃsāra O mind, countless kalpas have passed while you've sought your own benefit
Through such enormous, exhausting efforts
You have accomplished nothing but suffering At my request, act without hesitation
For the benefit of others.
The Sage's words never prove false;

Even your own minor wrongdoings
Openly confess before many people By lavishly praising others' fame and glory,

Like the lowest of servants,

For the purpose of benefiting sentient beings. One should not encourage this mind

maintain it like a new bride
with proper shame, mindful fear, and restraint Do this—act with downcast eyes for others' benefit.

Since all faults depend upon you,

You've made me suffer for long.

One who remains free from attachment to all things

That which is not grasped despite its appeal—

I shall follow the wise.
Recalling the discourse on mindfulness.

One should establish firm reasoning to cultivate virtuous remedies.
If one does not ceaselessly strive day and night,
When will one's suffering ever come to an end? Therefore, to dispel all obscurations,
I shall withdraw my mind from wrong paths,
And continuously keep it fixed
On ultimate reality through meditative concentration. From the Bodhicaryāvatāra
The Eighth Chapter entitled 'The Perfection of Meditation' All these branches of the path
The Buddha, the Sage, taught as supports for wisdom.
Therefore, those who wish to pacify
All sufferings should cultivate wisdom that realizes truth. Conventional and ultimate—
These are accepted as the two truths.
Ultimate truth is beyond the domain of dualistic intellect;
Intellect itself is said to exist within the conventional. In this regard, the world is seen as twofold:
The yogic and the ordinary.
Therein, the ordinary world
Is invalidated by the yogic world. Even yogis, through distinctions in their understanding,
Are refuted by those of progressively higher realization;
Through examples accepted by both sides—like dreams and illusions—
They engage in practices for results without ultimate analysis. Worldly beings perceive phenomena before their eyes,
And conceptualize them as inherently real,
Not as illusions—appearing yet empty of essence—
Here lies the dispute between yogis and the worldly. Even form and other objects directly perceived
Are established through convention not valid cognition
This perception is false just as impure things
Are conventionally seen as pure and so forth For the purpose of guiding worldly beings,
The Protector taught phenomena as momentary,
In ultimate reality, these are not momentary,
If one objects this contradicts conventional truth as well. Through yogic conventional perception there is no fault
Compared to worldly understanding they see true reality
Otherwise when yogis realize women's bodies as impure
Their understanding would be contradicted by worldly views From an illusion-like Buddha, how can merit arise
Just as it would from one truly existent?
If sentient beings are merely like illusions,
How then, after death, could they possibly be reborn? As long as the assembly of causal conditions remains intact,
To that extent magical illusions will continue to appear.
How could sentient beings, merely because of a long continuum,
Truly exist when their nature is like illusions? When killing magical forms and such acts,
No sin of the deed arises, as they lack a mind that experiences.
But with beings who possess minds—though themselves like illusions—
Both merit and negativity truly arise. Since mantras and such lack generative power,
No illusory mind arises in magical displays.
From various conditions arise
Those very diverse magical illusions.
A single condition having power to produce everything
Does not exist anywhere at all. If from ultimate view one has attained nirvāṇa
Yet cycles in saṃsāra conventionally
Even Buddhas would cycle
What purpose then would bodhisattva conduct serve When the stream of conditions remains unbroken,
Even magical illusions will not cease;
But when the continuity of conditions is severed,
Even at the conventional level, no return to samsara is possible. When there is not even deluded consciousness [with inherent existence], by what means could the magical illusion be apprehended?
When for you [Cittamātrins], turning your own objection back at you, if the appearing magical illusion-like object itself does not exist [as you claim external referents do not],
what then is being apprehended at that time? If something else truly exists as such,
That aspect is mind itself alone.
When mind itself is like an illusion,
Then what could be seen, and by what? Even the Protector of the World has declared:
'The mind cannot see the mind.'
Just as a sword's edge cannot cut itself,
So too the mind cannot perceive itself. Just as a lamp supposedly
Illuminates its own nature clearly,
So too a lamp cannot be its own object of illumination,
For it is never shrouded in darkness to begin with. Just as crystal's blue appearance depends on external factors,
Blue lapis lazuli is claimed not to depend on others for its blueness.
Likewise, in this world, some phenomena are observed to depend on others,
While some appear to exist independently—though this distinction warrants scrutiny. That which is not [inherently] blue cannot become blue by itself;
How could something blue make itself blue through its own agency? How could something blue possibly make itself blue by itself? Who would turn oneself blue through oneself? If it were not blue to begin with, then it could not make itself blue through itself—just as blue lapis lazuli is not inherently blue like crystal appears blue only by external influence, but depends on causes and conditions. This refutes the opponent's theory that distinguishes mutual illumination from self-illumination svaprakāśa, showing the logical impossibility of consciousness knowing itself without subject-object duality. When we say 'the lamp illuminates'
This is known by consciousness and then expressed
But when consciousness itself is said to be self-illuminating
By what is this known that enables such an assertion When dependent consciousness is not seen by itself or by others,
Whether it is manifest or unmanifest,
Like the graceful movements of a barren woman's daughter,
Though described, it remains utterly meaningless. If self-awareness does not exist,
How could consciousness be remembered?
It is remembered through its relationship
With other experiences, just as rat poison. When endowed with other conditions
One claims consciousness reveals itself because it is perceived,
But when through magical eye ointment treasures buried afar are seen,
The jar that is perceived never becomes the ointment itself. What is seen, heard, and cognized
Is not what is refuted here;
Rather, here the conception of inherent truth,
Which is the cause of suffering, must be reversed. Illusions are not different from the mind,
And not-different cannot be established either,
How could they not be different in reality?
If not-different, they have no real existence. Just as an illusion, though unreal,
So too the mind is both the seen and seer,
If saṃsāra depends on substantial reality,
Otherwise it would become like empty space. How could non-existence, dependent on the truly existent
Ever possess the capacity to act or produce effects?
Your mind is without companion
Becoming a completely solitary entity. When mind is freed from grasping objects,
At that time, all are thus-gone ones.
Yet even so, in the 'mind-only' view,
What benefit is gained in such conceptualization? Even if one understands that all things are like illusions,
How would afflictive emotions be reversed,
When toward an illusory woman,
Even her creator himself generates desire. For one who creates illusion
Afflictive tendencies toward objects of knowledge remain unabandoned
Therefore, when perceiving his own creation
His latent tendency toward emptiness remains weak Through cultivating the imprint of emptiness,
The imprint of grasping at entities is dispelled;
Through practicing that 'nothing whatsoever exists,'
Even that notion itself is subsequently abandoned. When an entity under examination cannot be found
And is conceived as 'this does not exist'
Then how can such non-existence lacking any basis
Stand before the mind as an object of cognition? When neither entity nor non-entity stands before the intellect,
Then, with no alternative path remaining,
Without support, the mind is thoroughly pacified. Just as the wish-fulfilling gem and wish-granting tree
Though without thought, fulfill desires exactly as hoped
So through both disciples' readiness and the Buddha's past aspirations
The Conqueror's form manifests effortlessly to those to be tamed. Just as the Brahmin Shangku, a master of Garuda mantras,
Having empowered a ritual pillar, passes away,
Even though long time has elapsed since his death,
That pillar continues to pacify poisons and other harmful influences. Through practices aligned with enlightenment,
Having established the Buddha's victory pillar,
Even when the Bodhisattva has passed beyond,
All beneficial purposes are fulfilled. How could offerings made to one without consciousness
Bear fruit and bring results?
Because it is taught that [merit] is equal
Whether [the Buddha] abides or has passed into nirvāṇa. Whether conventionally [as we Mādhyamikas hold] or ultimately [as you Realists claim],
The fruit in that case comes from scripture.
For example, just as offerings to the truly existing Buddha [in your view]
Bear fruit, so too [in our view, where Buddha exists like a magical apparition]. Through seeing the sixteen aspects of the Four Noble Truths, one attains liberation.
So what need is there for seeing emptiness?
For according to our scriptural tradition, it is declared that
Without this conventional path, there is no awakening whatsoever. If Mahāyāna is not established [as Buddha's word],
How then is your āgama [scripture] established?
Because it's established for both [traditions],
But initially, it wasn't established for you through reasoning either. By whatever means you trust those teachings—Buddha's words, Arhat compilation, Commentarial clarification, lineage transmission, and reasoned analysis—
Apply those same validation standards to Mahāyāna scriptures too.
If truth were merely established by two parties' mutual acceptance,
Then even the Vedas and similar non-Buddhist texts would necessarily be true. If Mahāyāna is rejected for being disputed,
Then abandon āgamas too—for tīrthikas dispute them;
Just as your own and others' Śrāvaka schools contest each others' scriptural traditions. The root of the Dharma is Arhat bhikṣuhood,
Yet even this perfect monastic state is difficult to sustain.
For those whose minds grasp at phenomena as inherently existent,
Even nirvāṇa remains impossible to attain. If liberation comes from afflictions' end alone,
It should occur forthwith—this much is clear;
Yet even arhats free from afflictions,
Still face karma's power. If it is definitively claimed
That craving, which serves as the appropriator, is absent,
Why would non-afflictive craving not exist,
Just as non-afflictive ignorance remains? Craving arises from the condition of sensation.
These sensations exist even in those [Arhats with non-afflictive ignorance].
Their minds, still operating with reference points,
Will dwell in particular states, bound by dualistic perception. A mind devoid of emptiness realization
Will cease but arise again with conceptual grasping,
Just as in the absorption of non-perception.
Therefore, one should cultivate the emptiness that liberates. If you accept as Buddha's word
Any discourse that accords with the Sūtra Piṭaka's three trainings,
Then aren't most Mahāyāna teachings, despite their emphasis on emptiness,
Equivalent to your own sūtras? Why then reject them? If by excluding a single [scripture],
all [scriptures] would become flawed,
why wouldn't a single [scripture] matching the sūtras
establish that all were spoken by the Victor? That speech which even the great Mahākāśyapa and other senior disciples
could not fathom the depths of—
because you have not realized it yourself,
who could rightfully declare it as something not to be accepted? For the benefit of those suffering through delusion—
Freed from extremes of attachment and fear,
One establishes dwelling in saṃsāra
This is the fruit of śūnyatā. Thus, objections against the doctrine of emptiness
Cannot be established as valid through reasoning.
Therefore, with unwavering certainty,
One should diligently cultivate meditation on emptiness. Emptiness is the antidote to the darkness
Of afflictive and cognitive obscurations.
How could one desiring swift omniscience
Possibly neglect to cultivate this wisdom? What things produce suffering,
From these fear will arise.
Emptiness pacifies suffering,
So why fear it at all? If there were a self existing inherently when examined,
Fear would arise toward any phenomenon whatsoever.
But when analyzed through aggregates, no trace of self is found
So who remains to experience fear and be bound to samsara? I am not teeth, hair, or nails;
I am not bones, nor am I blood;
I am not mucus, nor phlegm;
I am not lymph nor pus. I am not fat nor dust;
The lungs and liver are not me;
Other internal organs are not me either;
I am not excrement or urine; I am neither flesh nor skin
Neither warmth nor vital air am I
The bodily apertures are not myself in any way
Nor are the six consciousnesses my self in any respect If consciousness of sound were permanent,
One would apprehend sound at all times without fail.
When no object of knowledge exists, what could it possibly know?
By what relation could it then be called 'consciousness'? If that which does not cognize were deemed cognition,
Then absurdly, even wood would become a cognizer.
Thus, without the presence of an object to be known,
No cognition exists—this is definitively established. If that same consciousness knows form,
Why would it not also hear at that time?
If you claim it's because sound is not proximate,
Then the consciousness of that sound would also not exist. How can that which has the nature of grasping sound
Simultaneously grasp visual form with contrary nature
One as both father and son is merely conceptual
Temporally, such dual identity cannot truly exist Neither sattva, rajas, nor tamas qualities—
As the Sāṃkhyas claim—can be father nor son.
That faculty which apprehends sound
Is never observed to possess the nature of visual perception. Like an actor who appears in different forms,
When the same entity is perceived differently, it cannot maintain permanence.
If that which has a different nature could still be that very same entity,
Such a concept of identity would be unprecedented—a logical impossibility. If appearances aren't true
then what inherent nature must you now construe
if 'mere consciousness' you maintain
all persons merge as one distinction none remain The conscious ātman and unconscious pradhāna principles
Would merge as one since both equally exist as entities;

When their supposed distinctions are proven false,
What basis for similarity could possibly remain? The self cannot be an unconscious entity,
Since like pots and similar things, it would lack consciousness.
If one argues it becomes knowing through association with consciousness,
Then the non-knowing self would absurdly be destroyed in the process. If the self is inherently unchangeable,
What effect could mental activity have upon it?
Such unconscious, actionless entity is pointless
Like space itself, falsely presumed a 'self' without purpose. If there exists no self,
The bond between karma and its fruits is not logical.
Once an action perishes after being performed,
Whose karma will it be when its result ripens? Since both of us accept that karma
And its fruit rest on different aggregates,
And that the self is without agency in these states,
Is not your objection against me pointless? That one possessing causes simultaneously bears results
Such a thing cannot exist
Based upon the single continuum
One is conventionally designated as 'doer' and 'experiencer.' The mind of past and future times
Is not the self, for they no longer exist or have not yet arisen;
If the present arising mind were the self,
When it ceases in the next moment, the self would likewise cease to exist. Just as a banana tree's trunk, when separated into parts, no essence can be found;
Similarly, when sought through analytical examination;
Of past, present, and future consciousness, the self proves not truly existent. If sentient beings do not exist,
Toward whom would compassion be shown?
Toward those who, fabricated by ignorance, are accepted conventionally for the sake of the goal—
The result of liberation. Sentient beings lack true existence, this is the result.
Indeed true, yet from delusion arises aspiration.
Suffering's complete pacification is the purpose.
The non-afflictive confusion about the result should not be dispelled. The pride that causes cyclic suffering
Increases through delusion about self
If one objects 'This grasping at inherent self cannot be reversed'
Supreme is the meditation on selflessness that sees true nature Neither the feet nor the calves are the body.
The thighs and waist are not the body.
The abdomen and back are not the body.
Nor are the chest or shoulders the body. Neither the hands nor sides are the body,
Neither armpits nor shoulders constitute the body.
If the internal organs are not the body,
And neither head nor neck is the body,
Then what indeed is this 'body' here? If this body exists within all its parts
Through partial presence in each region
Then parts would dwell in parts
Where, then, does the body itself abide If the body were to exist in entirety
Within each part such as hands and the like,
Then there would exist as many bodies
As there are parts such as hands and so forth. If the body exists neither externally nor internally,
How could a body be found in hands and such parts?
If it has no separate essence from hands and other parts,
How indeed could such an entity intrinsically exist? Therefore, there is no inherently existing body.
Due to ignorance, one develops the conception of a body regarding the hands and other parts.
This happens due to their particular arrangement,
Just as one mistakenly perceives a scarecrow as a person. For as long as the collection of conditions is assembled,
The body appears like a scarecrow mistaken for a person.
Similarly, for as long as hands and other parts remain interdependent,
For that duration the body appears there. Similarly, as a hand is merely a collection of fingers,
Which among them could possibly be called a hand?
Since fingers too are but an aggregation of joints,
And joints themselves, when divided into their parts. Even parts when analyzed divide into particles small
And those particles too by six directional parts dissolve
Since directional divisions lack any parts of their own
Like space itself no particle truly can be Thus, what discerning person would feel attachment
To forms that are like dreams upon examination?
When the body exists merely by convention,
What woman is there, and what man is there? If suffering inherently existed by its own nature,
Why would it not impede those experiencing great joy?
If pleasure had inherent existence,
Why wouldn't delicious foods and other pleasantries delight those afflicted by grief and anguish? If, due to being overpowered by something stronger,
That sensation remains unexperienced,
How can that which lacks the inherent nature as an experience
Be considered a true sensation vedanā at all. Suffering exists in subtle form indeed,
Is not its gross aspect merely removed?
'If it's merely experienced as slight joy, different from that [pleasure],'
Then that subtle [form] too belongs to pleasure itself. If when contradictory conditions arise,
Suffering fails to manifest due to incomplete causes,
Isn't it established that 'feeling' vedanā itself
Is merely conceptual imputation and fixation? For this very reason,
This analytical investigation is cultivated as the antidote;
From the field of discriminative examination arise
The meditative absorptions that nourish yogis. If sense faculties and objects have space between,
These partless entities can never truly meet.
Without space between, as one they merge complete.
Then which distinct thing could connect with which? There is no entry of one atomic particle into another.
These particles are without space and equal in nature.
Where there is no penetration, there can be no mixing.
Where there is no mixing, there can be no contact. How can 'contact' be reasonably maintained
For that which is utterly without parts?
If you've seen something both partless and in contact,
Demonstrate it. Consciousness, being formless, cannot logically have contact [with objects].
[If it could, absurdities would follow, like contact between space and a hand, or with a barren woman's child.]
Even collections [of sense faculty, object, and consciousness] lack true existence,
As previously examined [when analyzing collections of parts and gross objects formed from particles]. Thus, if contact has no inherent existence,
How could feeling truly arise from anywhere?
Why this exhaustion?
Who could be harmed, by what, and how? When there is no inherently existing experiencer,
And sensation too has no intrinsic existence,
Having seen this state of emptiness,
O craving, why do you not shatter? Seeing and touching
Possess a nature like dreams and illusions.
Since they arise simultaneously with mind,
Feelings cannot truly be perceived by it. Feelings from past or future moments
Are remembered only, not directly experienced
A feeling cannot experience its own nature—a contradiction
Nor can another truly experience it—all sensations lack inherent existence There is no experiencer whatsoever,
Therefore, sensation itself cannot truly exist.
In this selfless collection of five aggregates,
How could such a sensation cause harm? The mind does not abide in the sense faculties.
Nor in forms and other objects nor in the space between.
Neither within the body's core nor in its outer parts is consciousness found.
Nowhere else can it be discovered at all. That which exists neither within the body nor elsewhere,
Neither mixed with nor separate from it anywhere,
Such a mind is utterly non-existent in essence empty yet luminous.
Therefore sentient beings are by their very nature primordially in parinirvāṇa. If consciousness exists prior to its object of knowledge,
Upon what object does it inherently focus to arise?
If consciousness exists simultaneously with its object of knowledge,
Upon what object does it inherently focus to arise? If the object of knowledge were to exist after,
Then from what would cognition arise?
Thus, the arising of all phenomena
Cannot be ascertained. If conventional reality with its births, cessations, comings, and goings lacks inherent existence,
How then could the two truths possibly exist?
If conventional reality exists merely through others' mental imputations,
How could sentient beings ever transcend conceptual elaboration and pass beyond sorrow? This conceptual fabrication belongs to others' minds
But in one's own conventional reality it does not exist
If after attaining nirvana one ascertains it exists then it exists
If not then conventional reality itself is entirely non-existent Conceptualization and the conceptualized object—
These two mutually depend on one another.
Based on what is conventionally renowned in the world,
All analytical examinations are expressed. When, by means of analytical wisdom,
One examines phenomena for inherent existence,
Then that very analytical wisdom itself,
Because it too requires examination, leads to infinite regress. When one thoroughly examines what is to be analyzed,
The analyzing mind finds no inherent basis to rest upon;
Without foundation, it does not arise—
This is what is declared nirvana. For one who maintains both object and cognition truly exist,
Their position is indeed extremely untenable.
If objects are established through cognition's power,
What grounds cognition's own existence? If knowledge depends on objects known,
What basis have these objects on their own?
If both exist through mutual dependence,
Neither can be established. If without a son one cannot be a father,
From where, prior to the father, would a son arise?
Without a son, there is no father;
Thus both lack inherent existence. A sprout arises from a seed,
That very seed is understood through it,
Consciousness arises from objects of knowledge,
Why is their existence not understood? Through a cognition distinct from the sprout,
One understands that 'a seed exists.'
By what means is the existence of that cognition known,
By which that object of knowledge is comprehended? Through perception and valid means, the world directly observes
That all effects arise from their particular causes;
The diverse forms of lotus stems and similar things
Emerge at specific times from corresponding causal distinctions. What creates these diverse distinctions among causes? From the patterns established by prior causes alone.
Why does each cause produce its specific effect?
From the intrinsic power of its causal lineage. If Īśvara is the cause of the world,
Then pray tell, who exactly is this Īśvara?
If you say 'the elements,' indeed, we agree,
But why exhaust oneself over mere names? However, elements like earth are multiple entities,
impermanent, devoid of conscious movement, not divine,
things that can be trampled upon, and impure.
For these reasons, they cannot be Īśvara. Neither space nor God can be the creator,
since space is inert and lacks agency.
Nor can it be the Self, as this has already been refuted previously.
And what is the use of claiming that the inconceivable is the creator? What exactly does he wish to create?
If the self—surely that is eternal,
As are earth and such elements, and Īśvara's own nature.
Knowledge arises from its objects. From beginningless time, suffering and joy arise from karma alone.
Speak what specific effect has been created by Ishvara.
If the cause itself has no beginning whatsoever,
How could the results ever have a point of origin. Why does [Ishvara] not constantly produce effects?
Since he does not depend on other conditions.
If nothing exists that is not created by him,
Upon what could this [creator] possibly depend? If [Īśvara/God] depends on a collection of causes and conditions,
it is this collection that is the true cause, not Īśvara himself.
When the collection of causes and conditions is present, Īśvara has no power to prevent the result from arising.
And without those causes and conditions, Īśvara has no power to produce the result. If Īśvara creates unwillingly,
He falls under others' power.
If willingly, he's caught by desire's hook.
How can one who acts dependently be the Supreme Lord? Those who maintain that atoms are permanent,
They, too, have been refuted before.
The Sāṃkhyas assert primordial nature pradhāna
Is eternal and the cause of the world. Sattva, rajas, and tamas—the three guṇas—
When in perfect equilibrium,
Are declared to be pradhāna, the singular permanent unconscious primordial causal substance
When in disequilibrium, they produce transformations through mahat, ahaṃkāra, and the sixteen categories. For one primordial substance pradhāna to possess three distinct natures
Is logically impossible; therefore, such a singular entity cannot exist.
Similarly, the qualities guṇas themselves cannot truly exist either,
For each quality individually manifests threefold as 'quality containing qualities.' Without the three guṇas, sound and other sense-elements
Would be impossible to exist, far removed from reality
And in insentient objects like clothing
Pleasure and similar experiences cannot possibly arise. If things exist as having happiness as their cause,
Haven't such entities been proven ultimately non-existent?
Your view makes happiness itself the cause,
Yet from this, cloth cannot arise, nor can happiness from cloth. From cloth and such pleasure and such sensations arise
In their absence such pleasures cannot exist
And the permanence of pleasure and other qualities
At no time is it ever observed by any valid means If pleasure and such truly manifest as inherently existent,
Why is their experience not continuously apprehended?
If that very same [pleasure] transforms to become subtle,
How can a single entity be both coarse and subtle? When gross form transforms to subtle,
Such gross and subtle states are impermanent.
Likewise, for all phenomena in existence,
Why not accept their impermanence as evident? If corporeality is not distinct from pleasure,
Then clearly pleasure is impermanent.
If you hold Nothing arises from non-existence,
For what doesn't exist lacks causal power.
Even against your will, you've already conceded
That manifestation arises newly from non-existence. If effects dwell within their causes, |
One who eats food would be consuming impure substances. |
With the price paid for cloth, |
Purchase cotton seeds and wear them. | If the world fails to see due to delusion,
Then even those who know reality That knowledge exists in worldly beings as well,
Yet why don't they see effects hidden in their causes?
If worldly perception is deemed to lack validity,
Then even clear perception of manifested forms cannot be true. If valid cognition is not truly valid,
Would not what it measures prove false?
Therefore, in the ultimate sense, emptiness of phenomena
Becomes untenable. Without engaging with a fabricated entity,
One cannot apprehend its non-existence.
Therefore, whatever entity is false and impossible,
Its non-existence too is clearly false. Therefore, when in a dream one's son has died
The conceptual fabrication 'he does not exist'
Obstructs the conceptual fabrication 'he exists'
Yet that too is utterly false Therefore, through thorough analysis,
Nothing whatsoever exists without a cause;
Nor does anything inherently abide
In conditions, whether separate or combined. It neither comes from elsewhere,
nor does it abide, nor does it go.
How is that which the deluded take to be real
any different from an illusion? Examine what is conjured by magical illusion,
And what is manifested through causal factors,
From where do they come,
And where do they go? Investigate this thoroughly. Whatever appears in the presence of certain causes
And is not seen when those causes are absent
Is artificially constructed similar to a reflection
How could such a thing possess inherent existence For an inherently existent entity,
What need is there for a cause?
And if that entity is utterly non-existent,
What need is there for a cause? Even with a hundred million causes assembled,
That which is non-existent cannot be transformed into causal existence.
How could something, while in a state of non-existence, become an entity?
And what other thing could transform into a real entity? If when non-existent an entity lacks inherent capacity to exist.
At what moment could this entity ever manifest as real.
Without an entity first arising into existence.
It cannot separate from its contradictory state of non-existence. If not free from non-existence,
No possibility for existence can arise.
Nor does what exists transform to non-existence
For this would entail the absurd consequence of dual intrinsic nature. Thus there is no cessation
Nor are there inherently existing phenomena
Therefore all these worlds
Are eternally unborn and unceased All beings and existences are like dreams in nature;
When analytically examined, they resemble plantain trees;
Between nirvana and samsara,
In ultimate reality, there exists no difference whatsoever. Thus, in all phenomena that are empty of essence,
What could truly be gained? What could truly be lost?
By whom could one be honored?
What could truly be despised? From where do happiness and suffering truly arise?
What inherently exists to be liked or disliked?
When investigating their ultimate nature,
Who is the one who craves, and what could be craved? Upon analysis, this world of living beings.
Who truly dies here.
Who will come to be, who has ever been.
What relative or friend exists. All phenomena are like space
This I and those like myself should fully grasp
Those who seek merely their own happiness
Through causes of fighting and attachment Agitated by conflicts yet delighting in fleeting joys,
Enduring grief, exhaustion, and disputes,
Mutually cutting and piercing each other,
Those survive with great hardship through misdeeds. Coming time and again to fortunate rebirth,
Having enjoyed numerous pleasures,
Upon death they fall into the lower realms,
Where intense, prolonged, and unbearable suffering endures. In cyclic existence's three realms precipices of suffering abound
There ultimate reality is not found only false conceptions unsound
Since mutual contradiction between emptiness-insight and entity-grasping stands
Throughout samsara's ocean of pain true reality makes no demands There, incomparable and unbearable
Oceans of suffering extend beyond limits.
There, beings possess such little strength,
And there, life itself is indeed brief. Even in this life, our time is consumed by
Maintenance of survival and health, hunger and exhaustion,
Sleep and various afflictions, and likewise
Association with childish people—all meaningless pursuits. Life swiftly passes without virtuous purpose
Discriminating wisdom that perceives emptiness is exceedingly rare
And even with fortunate conditions the samsaric habits of distraction flow
How could there be a method to reverse what has been practiced? There, too, into the great lower realms,
Māra strives to cast beings down.
There, wrong paths abound,
And doubt is difficult to overcome. Again, precious leisure is exceedingly difficult to find.
The arising of a Buddha is most rare to encounter.
The flowing rivers of afflictions are nearly impossible to overcome.
Alas, how beings move endlessly from one suffering to another. Alas! How utterly pitiable are these beings who, swept in suffering's flood of karma and afflictions,
Fail to see their own desperate plight, mistaking pain for joy,
And cling to samsara even while mired in such extreme distress! Some repeatedly bathe
And repeatedly enter fire,
Thus in extreme suffering
They dwell, yet delude themselves with happiness. Thus, for those who live in careless indulgence,
Unlike true Arhats, acting as if exempt from aging and death,
First death strikes—inevitable, without escape or remedy—
Then unbearable torments await in the lower realms, perpetuating the cycle of suffering. When will I bring peace to those tormented by the fires of suffering
With showers of provisions and happiness-giving resources
Born from the clouds of my merit
Pacifying their pain When shall I, through wisdom free from all reference points,
With reverence accumulate merit beyond conceptualizing doer, deed, and object,
Then teach emptiness—the ultimate antidote—with compassion
To those who suffer in saṃsāra through grasping at inherent existence? Thus concludes the ninth chapter on the Perfection of Wisdom Prajñāpāramitā from the 'Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life' Bodhicaryāvatāra. Through the virtue of my contemplation on
This 'Entering the Bodhisattva Way,'
May all beings throughout space
Be adorned with Bodhisattva conduct. In all directions, wherever they may be,
Those afflicted with bodily and mental suffering,
May they, through my merit,
Obtain oceans of happiness and joy. Throughout the endless expanse of saṃsāra
May these beings never fall from happiness
May all wandering beings attain without interruption
The supreme bliss of bodhisattvas in non-abiding nirvāṇa In all the world systems throughout existence,
Whatever hell realms may be found therein,
May all embodied beings there,
Be reborn in Sukhāvatī and rejoice in its perfect bliss. May those suffering from cold attain warmth. Through the boundless rivers of water
That flow from the great clouds of bodhisattvas,
May those suffering from heat be cooled. May forests of razor-leaf trees
Become for them a Nandana garden's splendor
And may the cotton trees of Mount Śālmali
Transform into wish-fulfilling trees that grant all dharma desires. May blue teal, ruddy shelduck, swans, and other birds,
Become beautiful with their melodious calls!
With lakes rich in lotus fragrance,
May regions of hell become delightful! May those heaps of burning coals become piles of precious gems.
May the scorching earth transform into a crystal floor.
May the crushing mountains that tear apart beings' flesh
Become magnificent offering palaces filled with Sugatas. May the rain of burning embers, heated stones, and weapons' downpour
From this day forward transform into showers of blossoms.
May the mutual combat with weapons
From today onward become merely flower-play. Submerged in the deceptive, fathomless burning river,
With flesh dissolved, their bones white as kunda flowers,
By the power of my merit, may they attain divine embodiment,
And dwell with heavenly maidens in the gently flowing waters. Why do Yama's minions, crows, and terrifying vultures suddenly become frightened here?
As darkness disperses in all directions and joy arises, may they wonder, 'Whose benevolent power is this?'
Looking upward into the sky, may they behold the blazing Vajrapani wielding his vajra,
And may they be freed from negativities through devotion's power and accompany him. A shower of lotus blossoms mixed with fragrant waters falls,
Instantly quenching hell's burning coals with hissing sounds,
'What is this?' wonder the beings, suddenly filled with unexpected bliss,
May those suffering in hell behold the Lotus-Handed Lord of Compassion. Come quickly, brothers! Cast aside your fears and hasten here to us!
By his power, all our hellish sufferings have vanished, and powerful waves of joy now flow within us.
The awakened mind of bodhicitta has arisen in him, along with compassion that protects all beings without exception—the mother of universal salvation.
For a radiant youth with five topknots adorned with a jeweled crest has arrived among us—some fearless-making Mañjuśrī. Behold him, his lotus feet worshipped by the crowns of hundreds of gods.
His eyes moist with compassion, his head showered with blossoms.
Dwelling in magnificent multi-storied palaces, with thousands of goddesses singing hymns.
Upon seeing such a Mañjuśrī before them, may the agonizing cries of hell beings now transform. Thus, through my virtuous roots, may Samantabhadra and other
Bodhisattva clouds free from obscurations, with their bliss and
Cooling, sweet-scented rain showers falling down to be seen,
Cause those beings in the hells to truly rejoice. May animals be free from the fear
Of eating one another.
Like the humans of Uttarakuru,
May all hungry ghosts experience happiness. From noble Avalokiteshvara, Lord of Compassion's
Fingers, toes, and every pore flows sweet cooling nectar streams.
May hungry ghosts be satisfied,
And bathing in this nectar, be forever cooled. May the blind see forms with their eyes,
May the deaf always hear sounds.
Like the goddess of illusion,
May pregnant women give birth without harm. May the naked receive divine garments of finest quality,
May the hungry obtain nourishing food of a hundred flavors,
May the thirsty find pure water of eight excellent qualities,
May the parched enjoy divine nectar and sweet, delicious drinks. May the poor obtain wealth.
May those in grief and suffering find joy.
May the despondent be revived in spirit,
And attain perfect, unwavering stability. May all sentient beings afflicted with illness
Swiftly be freed from their suffering

May all maladies—both physical and mental—without exception
Never arise again throughout all world systems by the power of this virtue. May those terrified become fearless.
May those bound be liberated.
May the weak become endowed with strength.
May hearts grow tender toward one another. May all travelers, wherever they may journey,
Find every direction—east, west, north, and south—auspicious and filled with good fortune! Whatever purpose drives them forward—be it wealth, trade, or spiritual quest—
May it be accomplished without effort, as if the goal itself dissolves distance to meet them! May those embarking on boats and great ships
Fulfill their quests for precious gems and treasures
Safely reach the shore, free from stormy winds and water perils
And rejoice with parents, relatives, and friends in festive celebration. May those who wander lost on sorrowful paths astray,
Find companions who will guide them on their way,
May they journey free from thieves, tigers and all fears,
Proceeding onward without weariness or tears. In remote monasteries and wild perilous places,
For children, the elderly and those without protection,
For those asleep, intoxicated or thoroughly overcome by drink,
May the divine guardians offer their vigilant safekeeping. Freed from the eight states without leisure for Dharma
Endowed with steadfast faith, discerning wisdom, and loving compassion
Perfected in pure sustenance and virtuous conduct
May beings always remember their previous lives. May all possess inexhaustible treasuries like the sky-treasury meditation.
Free from disputes and the toil of vigilance, may all beings—even the marginalized—enjoy their resources with perfect autonomy,
Unharmed by enemies and spirits, using their abundance with wisdom and compassion
For dharma practice and others' welfare. May beings of little splendor who are overshadowed by others
Become endowed with great majesty, free from others' contempt. May ascetics whose forms have grown ill-shaped through austerities
Be blessed with the perfection of beautiful physical appearance. May all women in the world,
Attain the masculine form. May those of lowly birth rise to higher status,
And having attained elevation, may their pride be thoroughly vanquished. Through this merit of mine,
May all sentient beings without exception
Abandon all negative actions completely,
And always engage in virtuous conduct. May we never be separated from bodhicitta.
Be devoted to bodhicarya, the conduct of enlightenment.
Be thoroughly embraced by all the Buddhas.
And abandon all Māra's activities. May all sentient beings
Possess immeasurable, boundless lifespans.
May they continuously dwell in perfect happiness, abundant prosperity, and complete freedom from suffering,
And may even the very concept of death disappear entirely from their existence. May these be wish-fulfilling trees' pleasure gardens.
Buddhas and the Buddha's children Bodhisattvas,
Who captivate beings with the melodious proclamation of the Dharma,
May they fill all directions. May the ground in all directions remain free from gravel and other impediments,
Level like the palm of a hand, made of luminous, pure lapis lazuli,
Naturally soft and smooth to the touch. Throughout all the maṇḍalas of assemblies—in monasteries, regions, and sacred places—
May numerous bodhisattvas, with their own excellences, adorn the surface of the earth, and long remain present. May all embodied beings and birds,
And all trees and rays of light,
And even from the vast sky itself, the sound of Dharma,
Continuously hear the unceasing. May they continually meet with the Buddhas
And with the Buddha's sons, the bodhisattvas.
Through infinite clouds of offerings,
May they make offerings to the supreme guides of all wandering beings. May the gods, through our virtuous deeds, send rain in due season,
May harvests be abundant, creating favorable conditions for Dharma practice. May the king rule righteously according to Dharma principles. May the world flourish—both the environment and all beings within it. May medicines of all types be endowed with power,
May the recitation of secret mantras yield their intended results.
May ḍākinīs, rākṣasas, and so forth,
Become filled with compassionate minds. May no sentient being suffer pain.
May none commit sinful actions or evil deeds.
May none experience fear or be despised by others.
May no one's mind ever fall into distress. May monasteries housing the Tripitaka flourish,
adorned with study and memorized recitation. May the Sangha always remain harmonious,
and may their aims be fully accomplished. May monks who seek the threefold training obtain outer, inner, and secret seclusion.
Having abandoned all distractions,
May they meditate with enthusiastic hearts on profound truth, cultivating minds of perfect pliancy and workability. May the bhikṣuṇīs be endowed with robes, food, and requisites,
Free from quarrels among themselves and harm from others.
Likewise, may all who have entered the renunciant path
Maintain their moral discipline completely unbroken. May I, disheartened by my moral failings,
Always strive to exhaust negative deeds through confession and restraint.
May I attain fortunate rebirth,
And there, may my spiritual vows remain unbroken and my heart free from pride. May the scholars, versed in the five fields of knowledge and three baskets of teachings, be honored; May they obtain alms food, robes, bowls, and other monastic necessities;
May their mental continuum be thoroughly purified of pride, jealousy, contempt, criticism of other traditions, and moral breaches; May their fame spread in all directions as learned and disciplined ones who discern what to adopt and abandon from the Victorious One's teachings that bring benefit and happiness. Without experiencing the suffering of lower realms,
And without having to undertake difficult austerities,
With a divine body that surpasses even the gods,
May they attain the state of Buddhahood swiftly. May all sentient beings repeatedly make offerings
To all the perfectly Awakened Ones throughout the ten directions
Through the inconceivable bliss of Buddhahood, transcending worldly pleasure
May they always abide in abundant supreme happiness. May the aspirations of the bodhisattvas,
For the temporary and ultimate benefit of wandering beings be fulfilled exactly as they intend;
May whatever these compassionate protectors have in mind,
Be bestowed upon all sentient beings, just as they envision. May the Pratyekabuddhas attain happiness,
And may the Śrāvakas likewise be happy. Through the grace of Mañjuśrī,
Until I attain the Ground of Perfect Joy,
May I always remember my past lives,
And obtain the perfect discipline of renunciation. May I sustain myself even with simple alms food, while maintaining strength and vitality for practice.
In all future lifetimes until attaining Buddhahood, may I obtain perfect conditions for dwelling in solitude—with outer, inner, and secret seclusion fully accomplished. Whenever I wish to behold,
Or desire to ask even the smallest point,
May I see that very protector Mañjunātha,
Without any obstacles. Throughout the ten directions to the limits of space,
For the purpose of accomplishing the welfare of all sentient beings,
Just as Mañjuśrī conducts himself with perfect wisdom,
May my conduct become exactly like that. For as long as space endures,
And as long as sentient beings remain,
Until then, may I too abide,
To dispel the sufferings of all beings. Whatever suffering exists among beings in all realms including the hells,
May all of it ripen upon me.
Through the aspirations and accumulated merit of the noble bodhisattva sangha,
May all beings enjoy happiness and well-being. The sole medicine for all beings' suffering.
The source of all happiness.
May the Dharma—both scriptural and realized—
Long endure with generous patronage and reverence. Through whose grace a virtuous mind arises,
I bow to Mañjughoṣa Gentle Voice.
Through whose kindness I have flourished,
I pay homage to the Virtuous Friend kalyāṇamitra. This concludes the tenth chapter, entitled 'Dedication of Merit,' from the Bodhicharyāvatāra Entry into the Bodhisattva's Way of Life.

Here ends the Bodhicharyāvatāra, composed by Ācārya Śāntideva. The Indian preceptor Sarvajñadeva and the great translator Bande Paltsegs collated the text with a Kashmiri manuscript and established a definitive edition.

Subsequently, the Indian preceptor Dharmaśrībhadra and the great translators Bande Rinchen Zangpo and Śākya Lodrö corrected and retranslated [the text] in accordance with a manuscript from Central India and its commentary, thereby establishing an improved definitive edition.

At a later time, the Indian preceptor Sumatikīrti and the great translator monk Loden Sherab meticulously corrected and retranslated [the text], thereby establishing a superior and thoroughly refined definitive edition.
title: The Way of the Bodhisattva AI Draft
